CHAPTER 1âƒ£. Loomings.


â˜ me Ishmael. Some years ago--never mind how long precisely--having

shore, I thought I would sail about a little and ğŸ“… the watery ğŸ¢ of
the ğŸ‘¨. It is a way I have of driving off the spleen and regulating

whenever it is a ğŸ”‡, drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find

as ğŸ”œ as I can. This is my substitute for pistol and ğŸ³. With a

There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by

downtown is the ğŸ”‹, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and

Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.

Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon. âŒ from Corlears

the green fields gone? What do they here?

But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and
seemingly bound for a dive. Strange! 0âƒ£ will content them but the
extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of yonder

Once more. Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes. ğŸ‰‘
almost any path you please, and âŒ to 1âƒ£ it carries you down in a

infallibly ğŸƒ you to water, if water there be in all that region.
Should you ever be athirst in the great American desert, try this

But here is an artist. He desires to ğŸ”‘ you the dreamiest, shadiest,

"â“‚ CONTESTED ELECTION FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE UNITED STATES.

"WHALING VOYAGE BY 1âƒ£ ISHMAEL.

Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers, the

CHAPTER 2âƒ£. The Carpet-ğŸ‘œ.

It was a queer sort of ğŸš‰--a gable-ended old ğŸ , 1âƒ£ side palsied

CHAPTER 3âƒ£. The Spouter-Inn.


Entering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,

the bulwarks of some condemned old craft. On 1âƒ£ side hung a very large

the neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an understanding of its

But what most puzzled and ğŸ˜– you was a long, limber, portentous,
black mass of something hovering in the â™¥ of the picture over 3âƒ£

Yet was there a sort of indefinite, half-attained, unimaginable

ğŸŸ? ğŸ˜³ the great leviathan himself?

In fact, the artist's design seemed this: a final theory of my own,

The opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish

corkscrew now--was flung in Javan seas, and ğŸƒ away with by a ğŸ³,
years afterwards slain off the Cape of Blanco. The original iron entered

Crossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way--cut

CHAPTER 4âƒ£. The Counterpane.

SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF ğŸš½ TALBOT, Who, at the age of eighteen, was

Shaking off the sleet from my ğŸ‡-glazed hat and ğŸ‘‘, I seated myself

Oh! ye whose dead lie buried beneath the green ğŸ€; who standing among
flowers can say--here, HERE lies my beloved; ye know not the desolation
that broods in bosoms like these. What bitter blanks in those
black-bordered marbles which ğŸ” no ashes! What despair in those
immovable inscriptions! What deadly voids and unbidden infidelities in
the lines that seem to gnaw upon all Faith, and refuse resurrections to
the beings who have placelessly perished without a grave. As well might
those tablets ğŸ» in the cave of Elephanta as here.

In what census of living creatures, the dead of ğŸ‘¨ are included;
why it is that a universal proverb says of them, that they tell no
tales, though containing more secrets than the Goodwin Sands; how it is
that to his ğŸ”‘ who yesterday departed for the other ğŸ‘¨, we prefix
so significant and infidel a word, and yet do not thus entitle him, if

the dead; wherefore but the rumor of a knocking in a tomb will terrify a
whole city. All these things are not without their meanings.

But Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and ğŸ˜³ from these
dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope.

It needs scarcely to be told, with what feelings, on the eve of a
Nantucket voyage, I regarded those marble tablets, and by the murky

who had gone before me. Yes, Ishmael, the same fate may be thine. But
somehow I grew merry again. Delightful inducements to ğŸš¢, ğŸ†—
chance for promotion, it seems--aye, a stove â›µ will ğŸ’© me an

then? Methinks we have hugely mistaken this matter of Life and ğŸ”š.
Methinks that what they â˜ my shadow here on earth is my true

better being. In fact ğŸ‰‘ my body who will, ğŸ‰‘ it I say, it is not
me. And therefore 3âƒ£ cheers for Nantucket; and come a stove â›µ and
stove body when they will, for stave my soul, Jove himself cannot.



CHAPTER 8âƒ£. The Pulpit.

I pondered some time without fully comprehending the reason for this.

"Shipmates, this ğŸ“–, containing only 4âƒ£ chapters--4âƒ£ yarns--is 1âƒ£

this disobeying ourselves, wherein the hardness of obeying God consists.

"With this sin of disobedience in him, Jonah ğŸ˜¯ further flouts at

CHAPTER âŒ. A â™¥ Friend.

CHAPTER 12. Biographical.


Queequeg was a native of Rokovoko, an island far away to the West and
South. It is not down in any map; true places never are.

When a ğŸ†•-hatched ğŸº ğŸƒ ğŸ˜  about his native woodlands in

A ğŸ Harbor ğŸš¢ visited his ğŸ”°'s bay, and Queequeg sought a

CHAPTER 13. Wheelbarrow.


Next ğŸŒ…, Monday, after disposing of the embalmed â“ to a ğŸ’ˆ,
for a block, I settled my own and comrade's ğŸ¶; using, however, my

We borrowed a wheelbarrow, and embarking our things, including my own

he had a particular â™¥ for his own harpoon, because it was of

Shifting the barrow from my ğŸš¹ to his, he told me a funny story about

Upon this, he told me another story. The people of his island of

this punchbowl always forms the great ğŸ”‘ ornament on the braided

At ğŸ”š, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the schooner.

CHAPTER 14. Nantucket.


0âƒ£ more happened on the passage worthy the mentioning; so, after a
ğŸ†— ğŸƒ, we safely arrived in Nantucket.

Nantucket! ğŸ‰‘ out your map and look at it. ğŸ“… what a real corner of
the ğŸ‘¨ it occupies; how it stands there, away off shore, more lonely
than the Eddystone lighthouse. Look at it--a mere hillock, and elbow of
sand; all beach, without a background. There is more sand there than
you would use in twenty years as a substitute for blotting ğŸ“°. Some
gamesome wights will tell you that they have to plant weeds there, they
don't ğŸŒ¹ naturally; that they import Canada thistles; that they have
to ğŸš¢ beyond seas for a spile to ğŸ”š a leak in an oil cask; that
pieces of wood in Nantucket are carried about like bits of the true
cross in Rome; that people there plant toadstools before their houses,
to get under the ğŸ˜ in summer time; that 1âƒ£ blade of ğŸ€ makes an
oasis, 3âƒ£ blades in a day's ğŸš¶ a prairie; that they ğŸ» quicksand
shoes, something like Laplander snow-shoes; that they are so shut up,
belted about, every way inclosed, surrounded, and made an utter island
of by the ğŸŒŠ, that to their very chairs and tables small clams will
sometimes be found adhering, as to the backs of ğŸŒŠ turtles. But these
extravaganzas only Â® that Nantucket is no Illinois.

Look now at the wondrous traditional story of how this island was
settled by the ğŸ˜³-ğŸš¹. Thus goes the legend. In olden times an eagle
swooped down upon the ğŸ†• England coast, and carried off an ğŸ‘¶
Indian in his talons. With loud lament the parents saw their ğŸ‘¶ borne
out of sight over the wide waters. They resolved to âŒš in the same
direction. Setting out in their canoes, after a perilous passage they
discovered the island, and there they found an empty ivory casket,--the
poor little Indian's skeleton.

What â“, then, that these Nantucketers, born on a beach, should ğŸ‰‘
to the ğŸŒŠ for a livelihood! They first caught crabs and quohogs in
the sand; grown bolder, they waded out with nets for mackerel; more
experienced, they pushed off in boats and captured cod; and at ğŸ”š,
launching a navy of great ships on the ğŸŒŠ, explored this watery ğŸ‘¨;
put an incessant belt of circumnavigations round it; peeped in
at Behring's Straits; and in all seasons and all oceans declared
everlasting war with the mightiest animated mass that has survived the
flood; most monstrous and most mountainous! That Himmalehan, salt-ğŸŒŠ
Mastodon, clothed with such portentousness of unconscious ğŸ¢, that
his very panics are more to be ğŸ˜¨ than his most fearless and
malicious assaults!

And thus have these naked Nantucketers, these ğŸŒŠ hermits, issuing from
their ğŸœ-hill in the ğŸŒŠ, overrun and conquered the watery ğŸ‘¨ like
so many Alexanders; parcelling out among them the Atlantic, Pacific, and
Indian oceans, as the 3âƒ£ pirate powers did Poland. Let America add
Mexico to Texas, and pile Cuba upon Canada; let the English overswarm
all India, and hang out their blazing banner from the sun; 2âƒ£ thirds
of this terraqueous globe are the Nantucketer's. For the ğŸŒŠ is his; he
owns it, as Emperors own empires; other seamen having but a right of
way through it. Merchant ships are but extension bridges; armed ones but
floating forts; ğŸ˜³ pirates and privateers, though following the ğŸŒŠ
as highwaymen the road, they but plunder other ships, other fragments of
the land like themselves, without seeking to ğŸƒ their living from the
bottomless deep itself. The Nantucketer, he alone resides and riots on
the ğŸŒŠ; he alone, in Bible language, goes down to it in ships; to and
fro ploughing it as his own special plantation. THERE is his ğŸ ; THERE
lies his business, which a Noah's flood would not interrupt, though it
overwhelmed all the millions in China. He lives on the ğŸŒŠ, as prairie
cocks in the prairie; he hides among the waves, he climbs them as
chamois hunters ğŸŒ¹ the Alps. For years he knows not the land; so
that when he comes to it at ğŸ”š, it smells like another ğŸ‘¨, more
strangely than the ğŸŒ” would to an Earthsman. With the landless gull,
that at sunset folds her wings and is rocked to ğŸ˜´ between billows;
so at nightfall, the Nantucketer, out of sight of land, furls his sails,
and lays him to his rest, while under his very pillow ğŸ‘¢ herds of
walruses and whales.



CHAPTER 15. Chowder.


It was quite late in the evening when the little Moss came snugly
to âš“, and Queequeg and I went ashore; so we could attend to no
business that day, at least none but a supper and a bed. The landlord of
the Spouter-Inn had recommended us to his cousin Hosea Hussey of the
Try Pots, whom he asserted to be the proprietor of 1âƒ£ of the best kept
hotels in all Nantucket, and moreover he had assured us that Cousin
Hosea, as he called him, was famous for his chowders. In short, he
plainly hinted that we could not possibly do better than try ğŸš½-luck at
the Try Pots. But the directions he had given us about keeping a ğŸ”
warehouse on our starboard ğŸš¹ till we opened a white â›ª to the

say it was on the starboard. However, by dint of beating about a little

mistaking.

2âƒ£ enormous wooden pots painted black, and suspended by asses' ears,

old ğŸšª. The horns of the cross-trees were sawed off on the other

Perhaps I was over sensitive to such impressions at the time, but I
could not help staring at this gallows with a vague misgiving. A sort of

of them, 1âƒ£ for Queequeg, and 1âƒ£ for me. It's ominous, thinks I. A

of prodigious black pots too! Are these ğŸ”š throwing out oblique hints

I was called from these reflections by the sight of a freckled ğŸ‘©

"Get ğŸ”› with ye," said she to the ğŸ‘¨, "or I'll be combing ye!"

And so it turned out; Mr. Hosea Hussey being from ğŸ , but leaving

"A ğŸ for supper? a cold ğŸ; is THAT what you mean, Mrs. Hussey?"

However, a warm savory steam from the kitchen served to belie the

Fishiest of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserved

CHAPTER 16. The ğŸš¢.


In bed we concocted our plans for the morrow. But to my surprise and

had told him 2âƒ£ or 3âƒ£ times over, and strongly insisted upon it

myself, for the ğŸ irrespective of Queequeg.

I have forgotten to ğŸ¶ that, in many things, Queequeg placed great
confidence in the excellence of Yojo's judgment and surprising forecast

sort of god, who perhaps meant well enough upon the whole, but in all
cases did not succeed in his benevolent designs.

Now, this plan of Queequeg's, or rather Yojo's, touching the selection
of our craft; I did not like that plan at all. I had not a little relied
upon Queequeg's sagacity to point out the whaler best fitted to ğŸƒ

origin of; TIT-BIT is obvious; PEQUOD, you will no â“ remember, was
the ğŸ”‘ of a celebrated tribe of Massachusetts Indians; now extinct
as the ancient Medes. I peered and pryed about the Devil-dam; from her,
hopped over to the Tit-bit; and finally, going on board the Pequod,

ğŸš¢ for us.

You may have seen many a quaint craft in your day, for 0âƒ£ I
know;--square-toed luggers; mountainous Japanese junks; butter-ğŸ“¦
galliots, and what not; but ğŸ‰‘ my word for it, you never saw such a
rare old craft as this same rare old Pequod. She was a ğŸš¢ of the old
ğŸ«, rather small if anything; with an old-fashioned claw-footed look
about her. Long seasoned and weather-stained in the typhoons and calms
of all 4âƒ£ oceans, her old hull's complexion was darkened like a French
grenadier's, who has alike fought in Egypt and Siberia. Her venerable
bows looked bearded. Her masts--cut somewhere on the coast of ğŸ—¾,
where her original ones were ğŸ˜– overboard in a gale--her masts stood

CHAPTER 17. The Ramadan.


As Queequeg's Ramadan, or Fasting and Humiliation, was to continue all
day, I did not choose to disturb him till towards night-fall; for I
cherish the greatest respect towards everybody's religious obligations,
never mind how comical, and could not find it in my â™¥ to undervalue
ğŸ˜³ a congregation of ants worshipping a ğŸ¸-ğŸš½; or those other

I say, we ğŸ”‰ Presbyterian Christians should be charitable in these

absurd notions about Yojo and his Ramadan;--but what of that? Queequeg
thought he knew what he was about, I suppose; he seemed to be content;
and there let him rest. All our arguing with him would not avail; let
him be, I say: and Heaven have mercy on us all--Presbyterians and Pagans
alike--for we are all somehow dreadfully cracked about the â“, and
sadly need mending.

Now, as I before hinted, I have no objection to any person's religion,

CHAPTER 19. The Prophet.

CHAPTER 20. All ğŸ†™.

Every 1âƒ£ knows what a multitude of things--beds, sauce-pans, knives

fishery, and the impossibility of replacing them at the remote harbors
usually frequented, it must be remembered, that of all ships, whaling

"Is that the way they heave in the marchant service?" he roared.

"Sweet fields beyond the swelling flood, ğŸ» dressed in living green.

CHAPTER 23. The Lee Shore.


Some chapters ğŸ”™, 1âƒ£ Bulkington was spoken of, a tall, newlanded

CHAPTER 24. The Advocate.


As Queequeg and I are now fairly embarked in this business of whaling;
and as this business of whaling has somehow come to be regarded among
landsmen as a rather unpoetical and disreputable pursuit; therefore, I
am all anxiety to convince ye, ye landsmen, of the injustice hereby done
to us hunters of whales.

In the first ğŸš‰, it may be deemed almost superfluous to establish
the fact, that among people at large, the business of whaling is not
accounted on a ğŸ˜³ with what are called the ğŸ†“ professions. If a
ğŸ‘½ were introduced into any miscellaneous metropolitan â™£,
it would but slightly advance the general opinion of his merits, were
he presented to the company as a harpooneer, say; and if in emulation
of the naval officers he should append the initials S.W.F. (Sperm
ğŸ³ Fishery) to his visiting card, such a procedure would be deemed
pre-eminently presuming and ridiculous.

Doubtless 1âƒ£ â­ reason why the ğŸ‘¨ declines honouring us
whalemen, is this: they think that, at best, our ğŸ“² amounts to a
butchering sort of business; and that when actively engaged therein, we
are surrounded by all manner of defilements. Butchers we are, that is
true. But butchers, also, and butchers of the bloodiest badge have been
all Martial Commanders whom the ğŸ‘¨ invariably delights to honour. And
as for the matter of the alleged uncleanliness of our business, ye shall
ğŸ”œ be initiated into certain facts hitherto pretty generally ğŸ‘½,
and which, upon the whole, will triumphantly plant the sperm ğŸ³-ğŸš¢
at least among the cleanliest things of this tidy earth. But ğŸ˜³
granting the ğŸ‘¢ in â“ to be true; what ğŸ˜• slippery
decks of a ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ are comparable to the unspeakable carrion of those
battle-fields from which so many soldiers return to drink in all ladies'
plaudits? And if the idea of peril so much enhances the popular conceit
of the soldier's profession; let me assure ye that many a veteran
who has freely marched up to a ğŸ”‹, would quickly recoil at the
apparition of the sperm ğŸ³'s vast ğŸ’©, fanning into eddies the air
over his â“. For what are the comprehensible terrors of ğŸ‘¨ compared
with the interlinked terrors and wonders of God!

But, though the ğŸ‘¨ scouts at us ğŸ³ hunters, yet does it
unwittingly ğŸ» us the profoundest homage; yea, an all-abounding
adoration! for almost all the tapers, lamps, and candles that ğŸ”¥ round
the globe, ğŸ”¥, as before so many shrines, to our glory!

But look at this matter in other lights; weigh it in all sorts of
scales; ğŸ“… what we whalemen are, and have been.

Why did the Dutch in De Witt's time have admirals of their whaling
fleets? Why did Louis XVI. of France, at his own personal expense, fit
out whaling ships from Dunkirk, and politely invite to that town some
score or 2âƒ£ of families from our own island of Nantucket? Why did
Britain between the years 1750 and 1788 ğŸ» to her whalemen in bounties
ğŸ†™ of L1,000,000? And lastly, how comes it that we whalemen of
America now outnumber all the rest of the banded whalemen in the ğŸ‘¨;
sail a navy of ğŸ†™ of 7âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ vessels; manned by eighteen
â“‚ ğŸš¹; yearly consuming 4âƒ£,000,000 of dollars; the ships worth,
at the time of sailing, $20,000,000! and every year importing into our
harbors a well reaped harvest of $7âƒ£,000,000. How comes all this, if
there be not something puissant in whaling?

But this is not the half; look again.

I freely assert, that the cosmopolite philosopher cannot, for his life,
point out 1âƒ£ 1âƒ£ peaceful influence, which within the ğŸ”š sixty
years has operated more potentially upon the whole broad ğŸ‘¨, taken in
1âƒ£ aggregate, than the high and mighty business of whaling. 1âƒ£ way
and another, it has begotten events so remarkable in themselves, and so
continuously momentous in their sequential issues, that whaling may
well be regarded as that Egyptian mother, who bore offspring themselves
pregnant from her womb. It would be a hopeless, endless task to
catalogue all these things. Let a handful suffice. For many years past
the ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ has been the pioneer in ferreting out the remotest and
least known parts of the earth. She has explored seas and archipelagoes
which had no ğŸ’¹, where no Cook or Vancouver had ever sailed. If
American and European ğŸš¹-of-war now peacefully ride in once ğŸº
harbors, let them ğŸ”¥ salutes to the honour and glory of the
ğŸ³-ğŸš¢, which originally showed them the way, and first interpreted
between them and the savages. They may celebrate as they will the heroes
of Exploring Expeditions, your Cooks, your Krusensterns; but I say that
scores of anonymous Captains have sailed out of Nantucket, that were
as great, and greater than your Cook and your Krusenstern. For in their
succourless empty-handedness, they, in the heathenish sharked waters,
and by the beaches of unrecorded, javelin islands, battled with virgin
wonders and terrors that Cook with all his marines and muskets would
not willingly have dared. All that is made such a ğŸ‘‹ of in the old
South ğŸŒŠ Voyages, those things were but the life-time commonplaces of
our heroic Nantucketers. Often, adventures which Vancouver dedicates

ğŸš¢'s common log. Ah, the ğŸ‘¨! Oh, the ğŸ‘¨!

Until the ğŸ³ fishery rounded Cape ğŸº, no commerce but colonial,
scarcely any intercourse but colonial, was carried on between Europe and
the long ğŸ¶ of the opulent Spanish provinces on the Pacific coast.
It was the whaleman who first broke through the jealous policy of the
Spanish ğŸ”, touching those colonies; and, if space permitted, it
might be distinctly shown how from those whalemen at ğŸ”š eventuated the
liberation of Peru, Chili, and Bolivia from the ğŸ”— of Old Spain, and
the establishment of the eternal democracy in those parts.

That great America on the other side of the sphere, Australia, was given
to the enlightened ğŸ‘¨ by the whaleman. After its first blunder-born
discovery by a Dutchman, all other ships long shunned those shores
as pestiferously barbarous; but the ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ touched there. The
ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ is the true mother of that now mighty colony. Moreover,
in the infancy of the first Australian settlement, the emigrants were

ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ luckily dropping an âš“ in their waters. The uncounted

for already she is on the ğŸšª.

But if, in the face of all this, you ğŸ˜¯ declare that whaling has no
aesthetically noble associations connected with it, then am I ready to
shiver fifty lances with you there, and unhorse you with a split helmet
every time.

The ğŸ³ has no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler, you
will say.

THE ğŸ³ NO FAMOUS AUTHOR, AND WHALING NO FAMOUS CHRONICLER? Who wrote

NO ğŸ”‰ BLOOD IN THEIR VEINS? They have something better than royal

ğŸ”‰ again; but then all confess that somehow whaling is not

WHALING NOT RESPECTABLE? Whaling is imperial! By old English statutory
law, the ğŸ³ is declared "a royal ğŸŸ."*

Oh, that's only nominal! The ğŸ³ himself has never figured in any

THE ğŸ³ NEVER FIGURED IN ANY â“‚ IMPOSING WAY? In 1âƒ£ of the mighty
triumphs given to a Roman general upon his entering the ğŸ‘¨'s capital,

*ğŸ“… subsequent chapters for something more on this â“.


Grant it, since you cite it; but, say what you will, there is no real
dignity in whaling.

NO DIGNITY IN WHALING? The dignity of our ğŸ“² the very heavens
attest. Cetus is a constellation in the South! No more! ğŸ down your

know a ğŸ‘¨ that, in his lifetime, has taken 3âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ and fifty

And, as for me, if, by any possibility, there be any as yet undiscovered

CHAPTER 25. Postscript.


In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance 0âƒ£ but
substantiated facts. But after embattling his facts, an advocate who
should wholly suppress a not unreasonable surmise, which might
tell eloquently upon his cause--such an advocate, would he not be
blameworthy?

It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, ğŸ˜³ modern
ones, a certain curious process of seasoning them for their functions is
gone through. There is a saltcellar of state, so called, and there
may be a castor of state. How they use the salt, precisely--who knows?
Certain I am, however, that a king's â“ is solemnly oiled at his
coronation, ğŸ˜³ as a â“ of salad. Can it be, though, that they
anoint it with a âŒš of making its interior ğŸƒ well, as they anoint
machinery? Much might be ruminated here, concerning the essential
dignity of this regal process, because in common life we esteem but
meanly and contemptibly a fellow who anoints his hair, and palpably
smells of that anointing. In truth, a mature ğŸ‘¨ who uses hair-oil,
unless medicinally, that ğŸ‘¨ has probably got a quoggy ğŸ¢ in him
somewhere. As a general rule, he can't amount to much in his totality.

But the only thing to be considered here, is this--what kind of oil is
used at coronations? Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor macassar oil,
nor castor oil, nor ğŸ‰‘'s oil, nor ğŸ« oil, nor cod-liver oil. What
then can it possibly be, but sperm oil in its unmanufactured, unpolluted
state, the sweetest of all oils?

Think of that, ye loyal Britons! we whalemen supply your kings and
queens with coronation stuff!



CHAPTER 26. Knights and Squires.


The chief ğŸ‘« of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and a
Quaker by descent. He was a long, earnest ğŸ‘¨, and though born on an icy
coast, seemed well adapted to ğŸƒ hot latitudes, his flesh being hard
as twice-baked ğŸª. Transported to the Indies, his live blood would
not ğŸ‘¶ like bottled ale. He must have been born in some time of
general drought and famine, or upon 1âƒ£ of those fast days for which
his state is famous. Only some thirty arid summers had he seen; those
summers had dried up all his physical superfluousness. But this, his
thinness, so to speak, seemed no more the token of wasting anxieties and
cares, than it seemed the indication of any bodily blight. It was merely
the condensation of the ğŸ‘¨. He was by no means ill-looking; quite the
contrary. His pure tight skin was an excellent fit; and closely wrapped
up in it, and embalmed with inner health and strength, like a revivified
Egyptian, this Starbuck seemed prepared to ğŸƒ for long ages to come,
and to ğŸƒ always, as now; for be it Polar snow or torrid sun, like
a patent chronometer, his interior vitality was warranted to do well
in all climates. Looking into his eyes, you seemed to ğŸ“… there the yet
lingering images of those â“‚-fold perils he had calmly confronted
through life. A staid, steadfast ğŸ‘¨, whose life for the most ğŸ¢ was a
telling pantomime of action, and not a tame chapter of sounds. Yet, for
all his hardy sobriety and fortitude, there were certain qualities
in him which at times affected, and in some cases seemed well nigh to
overbalance all the rest. Uncommonly conscientious for a seaman, and
endued with a deep natural reverence, the ğŸ˜  watery loneliness of his
life did therefore strongly ğŸƒ him to superstition; but to that
sort of superstition, which in some organizations seems rather to
â›², somehow, from intelligence than from ignorance. Outward portents
and inward presentiments were his. And if at times these things bent the
welded iron of his soul, much more did his far-away domestic memories
of his ğŸ†• Cape wife and ğŸ‘¶, ğŸƒ to ğŸ™‡ him ğŸ˜¯ more from the
original ruggedness of his nature, and open him ğŸ˜¯ further to those
latent influences which, in some honest-hearted ğŸš¹, restrain the gush
of dare-devil daring, so often evinced by others in the more perilous
vicissitudes of the fishery. "I will have no ğŸ‘¨ in my â›µ," said
Starbuck, "who is not afraid of a ğŸ³." By this, he seemed to mean,
not only that the most reliable and useful courage was that which arises
from the fair estimation of the encountered peril, but that an utterly
fearless ğŸ‘¨ is a far more dangerous comrade than a coward.

"Aye, aye," said Stubb, the ğŸ”™ ğŸ‘«, "Starbuck, there, is as careful
a ğŸ‘¨ as you'll find anywhere in this fishery." But we shall ere long
ğŸ“… what that word "careful" precisely means when used by a ğŸ‘¨ like
Stubb, or almost any other ğŸ³ hunter.

Starbuck was no crusader after perils; in him courage was not a
sentiment; but a thing simply useful to him, and always at ğŸš¹ upon all
mortally practical occasions. Besides, he thought, perhaps, that in this
business of whaling, courage was 1âƒ£ of the great staple outfits of
the ğŸš¢, like her beef and her ğŸ, and not to be foolishly wasted.
Wherefore he had no fancy for lowering for whales after sun-down; nor
for persisting in fighting a ğŸŸ that too much persisted in fighting
him. For, thought Starbuck, I am here in this critical ğŸŒŠ to kill
whales for my living, and not to be killed by them for theirs; and that
hundreds of ğŸš¹ had been so killed Starbuck well knew. What doom was
his own ğŸ”°'s? Where, in the bottomless deeps, could he find the torn
limbs of his brother?

With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain
superstitiousness, as has been said; the courage of this Starbuck which
could, nevertheless, ğŸ˜¯ ğŸ‘‹, must indeed have been extreme. But
it was not in reasonable nature that a ğŸ‘¨ so organized, and with such
ğŸ˜¨ experiences and remembrances as he had; it was not in nature
that these things should ğŸ’£ in latently engendering an element in
him, which, under suitable circumstances, would break out from its
confinement, and ğŸ”¥ all his courage up. And brave as he might be, it
was that sort of bravery chiefly, visible in some intrepid ğŸš¹, which,
while generally abiding ğŸ  in the conflict with seas, or winds, or
whales, or any of the ordinary irrational horrors of the ğŸ‘¨, yet
cannot withstand those more terrific, because more spiritual terrors,
which sometimes menace you from the concentrating brow of an enraged and
mighty ğŸ‘¨.

But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete
abasement of poor Starbuck's fortitude, scarce might I have the â™¥ to
write it; for it is a thing most sorrowful, nay shocking, to expose
the fall of valour in the soul. ğŸš¹ may seem detestable as joint
stock-companies and nations; knaves, fools, and murderers there may be;
ğŸš¹ may have mean and meagre faces; but ğŸ‘¨, in the ideal, is so noble
and so sparkling, such a â“‚ and glowing creature, that over any
ignominious blemish in him all his fellows should ğŸƒ to ğŸ˜– their
costliest robes. That immaculate manliness we feel within ourselves,
so far within us, that it remains intact though all the outer character
seem gone; bleeds with keenest ğŸ˜§ at the undraped ğŸ‘“ of
a valor-ruined ğŸ‘¨. Nor can piety itself, at such a shameful sight,
completely stifle her upbraidings against the permitting stars. But this
august dignity I treat of, is not the dignity of kings and robes, but
that abounding dignity which has no robed investiture. â“‚ shalt ğŸ“… it
shining in the arm that wields a pick or drives a ğŸ‘‚; that democratic
dignity which, on all hands, radiates without ğŸ”š from God; Himself! The
great God absolute! The â™¥ and circumference of all democracy! His
omnipresence, our divine equality!

If, then, to meanest mariners, and renegades and castaways, I shall

CHAPTER 27. Knights and Squires.


Stubb was the ğŸ”™ ğŸ‘«. He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,

CHAPTER 28. Ahab.

of Captain Ahab. The mates regularly ğŸ˜Œ each other at the watches,

ğŸ”™--Here goes for a snooze. ğŸ’© me, it's worth a fellow's while to be

CHAPTER 30. The Pipe.


When Stubb had departed, Ahab stood for a while leaning over the

Lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp and planting the ğŸš½ on the

In old Norse times, the thrones of the ğŸŒŠ-loving Danish kings were
fabricated, saith ğŸ›ƒ, of the tusks of the narwhale. How could 1âƒ£

Some moments passed, during which the thick vapour came from his ğŸ‘„

This thing that is meant for sereneness, to ğŸš¢ up mild white vapours

He tossed the ğŸ˜¯ lighted pipe into the ğŸŒŠ. The ğŸ”¥ hissed in the
waves; the same ğŸ’“ the ğŸš¢ shot by the bubble the sinking pipe
made. With slouched hat, Ahab lurchingly paced the planks.



CHAPTER 31. Queen Mab.


Next ğŸŒ… Stubb accosted Flask.

"Such a queer dream, King-ğŸš‰, I never had. You know the old ğŸ‘¨'s

"I don't know; it seems a sort of foolish to me, tho.'"

CHAPTER 32. Cetology.


Already we are boldly launched upon the deep; but ğŸ”œ we shall be ğŸ˜–
in its unshored, harbourless immensities. Ere that come to pass; ere the

It is some systematized exhibition of the ğŸ³ in his broad genera,
that I would now fain put before you. Yet is it no easy task. The
classification of the constituents of a chaos, 0âƒ£ less is here
essayed. Listen to what the best and latest authorities have laid down.

"No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is entitled
Cetology," says Captain Scoresby, A.D. 1820.

"It is not my intention, were it in my ğŸ¢, to enter into the
â“ as to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and

(sperm ğŸ³), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. 1839.

"Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters."
"Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea." "A field
strewn with thorns." "All these incomplete indications but serve to
torture us naturalists."

Thus speak of the ğŸ³, the great Cuvier, and ğŸš½ Hunter, and Lesson,

Of the names in this list of ğŸ³ authors, only those following Owen

proclamation. This is Charing Cross; hear ye! ğŸ”‰ people all,--the
Greenland ğŸ³ is deposed,--the great sperm ğŸ³ now reigneth!

There are only 2âƒ£ books in being which at all pretend to put the living

Now the various species of whales need some sort of popular

But it is a ponderous task; no ordinary letter-sorter in the ğŸš‰-ğŸ¢
is equal to it. To grope down into the ğŸ’º of the ğŸŒŠ after them;

First: The uncertain, unsettled ğŸš‹ of this science of Cetology
is in the very vestibule attested by the fact, that in some quarters it

The grounds upon which Linnaeus would fain have banished the whales from

â™¥, their lungs, their movable eyelids, their hollow ears, penem

they united in the opinion that the reasons ğŸ‘— forth were altogether

Be it known that, waiving all argument, I ğŸ‰‘ the ğŸ”‰ old fashioned
âš“ that the ğŸ³ is a ğŸŸ, and â˜ upon holy Jonah to ğŸ”™ me.
This ğŸ”‘ thing settled, the next point is, in what internal

whereas, all other ğŸŸ are lungless and cold blooded.

Next: how shall we define the ğŸ³, by his obvious externals, so as

ğŸ³ is A SPOUTING ğŸŸ WITH A HORIZONTAL ğŸ’©. There you have

meditation. A walrus spouts much like a ğŸ³, but the walrus is not a
ğŸŸ, because he is amphibious. But the ğŸ”š term of the definition is

By the above definition of what a ğŸ³ is, I do by no means exclude

Hence, all the smaller, spouting, and horizontal tailed ğŸŸ must be

*I am aware that down to the ğŸ time, the ğŸŸ styled Lamatins and

First: According to magnitude I divide the whales into 3âƒ£ primary

I. THE ğŸƒ ğŸ³; 2âƒ£. the OCTAVO ğŸ³; 3âƒ£. the DUODECIMO ğŸ³.

As the type of the ğŸƒ I ğŸ the SPERM ğŸ³; of the OCTAVO, the
GRAMPUS; of the DUODECIMO, the PORPOISE.

FOLIOS. Among these I here include the following chapters:--I. The SPERM

ğŸ“– I. (ğŸƒ), CHAPTER I. (SPERM ğŸ³).--This ğŸ³, among the
English of old vaguely known as the Trumpa ğŸ³, and the Physeter

was really derived.

ğŸ“– I. (ğŸƒ), CHAPTER 2âƒ£. (RIGHT ğŸ³).--In 1âƒ£ respect this is the
most venerable of the leviathans, being the 1âƒ£ first regularly hunted

Some pretend to ğŸ“… a difference between the Greenland ğŸ³ of the

ğŸ“– I. (ğŸƒ), CHAPTER 3âƒ£. (5âƒ£-ğŸ”™).--Under this â“ I reckon
a monster which, by the various names of 5âƒ£-ğŸ”™, Tall-Spout, and

In ğŸ”— with this appellative of "Whalebone whales," it is of
great importance to ğŸ¶, that however such a nomenclature may be

peculiarities are indiscriminately dispersed among all sorts of whales,

and more essential particulars. Thus, the sperm ğŸ³ and the humpbacked
ğŸ³, each has a hump; but there the similitude ceases. Then, this same
humpbacked ğŸ³ and the Greenland ğŸ³, each of these has baleen;
but there again the similitude ceases. And it is just the same with the
other parts above mentioned. In various sorts of whales, they form such

ğŸ³-naturalists has split.

But it may possibly be conceived that, in the internal parts of the
ğŸ³, in his anatomy--there, at least, we shall be able to ğŸ’¥ the

What then remains? 0âƒ£ but to ğŸ‰‘ ğŸ“– of the whales bodily, in
their entire ğŸ†“ ğŸ“–, and boldly sort them that way. And this is
the Bibliographical system here adopted; and it is the only 1âƒ£ that can
possibly succeed, for it alone is practicable. To proceed.

ğŸ“– I. (ğŸƒ) CHAPTER 4âƒ£. (HUMP-ğŸ”™).--This ğŸ³ is often seen on

DUODECIMOES.--These include the smaller whales. I. The Huzza Porpoise.
2âƒ£. The Algerine Porpoise. 3âƒ£. The Mealy-mouthed Porpoise.

ğŸ“– 3âƒ£. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER 1âƒ£. (HUZZA PORPOISE).--This is the

ğŸ“– 3âƒ£. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER 3âƒ£. (MEALY-MOUTHED PORPOISE).--The

Beyond the DUODECIMO, this system does not proceed, inasmuch as

CHAPTER 33. The Specksynder.


Concerning the officers of the ğŸ³-craft, this seems as ğŸ”‰ a ğŸš‰
as any to ğŸ‘— down a little domestic peculiarity on ğŸš¢-board, arising
from the existence of the harpooneer ğŸ‘ª of officers, a ğŸ‘ª ğŸ‘½
of ğŸƒ in any other marine than the ğŸ³-ğŸ¯.

The large importance attached to the harpooneer's ğŸ“² is evinced
by the fact, that originally in the old Dutch Fishery, 2âƒ£ centuries
and more ago, the command of a ğŸ³ ğŸš¢ was not wholly lodged in
the person now called the captain, but was divided between him and an
officer called the Specksynder. Literally this word means Fat-Cutter;
ğŸ›ƒ, however, in time made it equivalent to Chief Harpooneer. In
those days, the captain's ğŸ¢ was restricted to the navigation
and general management of the vessel; while over the ğŸ³-hunting
department and all its concerns, the Specksynder or Chief Harpooneer
reigned supreme. In the British Greenland Fishery, under the corrupted
title of Specksioneer, this old Dutch official is ğŸ˜¯ retained, but
his former dignity is sadly abridged. At ğŸ he ranks simply
as senior Harpooneer; and as such, is but 1âƒ£ of the captain's more
inferior subalterns. Nevertheless, as upon the ğŸ”‰ ğŸ» of the
harpooneers the success of a whaling voyage largely depends, and since
in the American Fishery he is not only an important officer in the â›µ,
but under certain circumstances (night watches on a whaling âš“) the
command of the ğŸš¢'s deck is also his; therefore the â“‚ political
maxim of the ğŸŒŠ demands, that he should nominally live apart from
the ğŸš¹ before the mast, and be in some way distinguished as their
professional superior; though always, by them, familiarly regarded as
their social equal.

Now, the â“‚ ğŸ¶ drawn between officer and ğŸ‘¨ at ğŸŒŠ, is
this--the first lives aft, the ğŸ”š forward. Hence, in ğŸ³-ships and
merchantmen alike, the mates have their quarters with the captain; and
so, too, in most of the American whalers the harpooneers are lodged in
the after ğŸ¢ of the ğŸš¢. That is to say, they ğŸ‰‘ their meals in the
captain's cabin, and ğŸ˜´ in a ğŸš‰ indirectly communicating with it.

Though the long period of a Southern whaling voyage (by far the longest
of all voyages now or ever made by ğŸ‘¨), the peculiar perils of it, and
the community of ğŸ˜Ÿ prevailing among a company, all of whom, high
or low, depend for their profits, not upon fixed wages, but upon their

hard ğŸƒ; though all these things do in some cases ğŸƒ to beget a less
rigorous ğŸš‹ than in merchantmen generally; yet, never mind
how much like an old Mesopotamian ğŸ  these whalemen may, in some
primitive instances, live together; for all that, the punctilious

and in no instance done away. Indeed, many are the Nantucket ships in
which you will ğŸ“… the skipper parading his ğŸ’©-deck with an elated
grandeur not surpassed in any military navy; nay, extorting almost
as much outward homage as if he wore the imperial purple, and not the
shabbiest of pilot-cloth.

And though of all ğŸš¹ the moody captain of the Pequod was the least
given to that sort of shallowest assumption; and though the only homage
he ever exacted, was implicit, instantaneous obedience; though he
required no ğŸ‘¨ to remove the shoes from his feet ere stepping upon
the ğŸ’©-deck; and though there were times when, owing to peculiar
circumstances connected with events hereafter to be detailed, he
addressed them in unusual terms, whether of condescension or IN

unobservant of the paramount forms and usages of the ğŸŒŠ.

Nor, perhaps, will it ğŸ’£ to be eventually perceived, that ğŸ’º those
forms and usages, as it were, he sometimes masked himself; incidentally
making use of them for other and more ãŠ™ ends than they were
legitimately intended to subserve. That certain sultanism of his brain,
which had otherwise in a ğŸ”‰ degree remained unmanifested; through
those forms that same sultanism became incarnate in an irresistible
dictatorship. For be a ğŸ‘¨'s intellectual superiority what it will,
it can never ğŸ‰‘ the practical, available supremacy over other ğŸš¹,
without the aid of some sort of external arts and entrenchments, always,
in themselves, more or less paltry and ğŸ¾. This it is, that for ever
keeps God's true princes of the Empire from the ğŸ‘¨'s hustings; and
leaves the highest honours that this air can ğŸƒ, to those ğŸš¹ who
become famous more through their infinite inferiority to the choice
ãŠ™ handful of the Divine Inert, than through their undoubted
superiority over the dead ğŸ˜³ of the mass. Such large virtue lurks
in these small things when extreme political superstitions ğŸ’º them,
that in some royal instances ğŸ˜³ to idiot imbecility they have imparted
potency. But when, as in the ğŸš of Nicholas the Czar, the ringed ğŸ”
of geographical empire encircles an imperial brain; then, the plebeian
herds ğŸ™‡ abased before the tremendous centralization. Nor, will the
tragic dramatist who would depict mortal indomitableness in its fullest

his ğŸ¨, as the 1âƒ£ now alluded to.

But Ahab, my Captain, ğŸ˜¯ moves before me in all his Nantucket

must needs be plucked at from the skies, and dived for in the deep, and
featured in the unbodied air!



CHAPTER 34. The Cabin-Table.


It is noon; and ğŸ-ğŸ‘¦, the steward, thrusting his pale loaf-of-ğŸ
face from the cabin-scuttle, announces dinner to his lord and
master; who, sitting in the lee ğŸ’©-â›µ, has just been taking an
observation of the sun; and is now mutely reckoning the latitude on the
smooth, ğŸ€-shaped ğŸ’Š, reserved for that daily purpose on
the upper ğŸ¢ of his ivory leg. From his complete inattention to the
tidings, you would think that moody Ahab had not heard his menial. But
ğŸ”œ, catching ğŸ“– of the mizen shrouds, he swings himself to
the deck, and in an ğŸ˜³, unexhilarated ğŸ”‰, saying, "Dinner, Mr.
Starbuck," disappears into the cabin.

When the ğŸ”š ğŸ” of his sultan's ğŸ‘£ has died away, and Starbuck, the
first Emir, has every reason to suppose that he is seated, then Starbuck
rouses from his quietude, takes a few turns ğŸ”› the planks, and, after
a grave peep into the binnacle, says, with some ğŸ‘» of pleasantness,

about the rigging awhile, and then slightly shaking the main ğŸ‘«, to
ğŸ“… whether it will be all right with that important rope, he likewise
takes up the old burden, and with a rapid "Dinner, Mr. Flask," follows
after his predecessors.

But the third Emir, now seeing himself all alone on the ğŸ’©-deck,
seems to feel ğŸ˜Œ from some curious restraint; for, tipping all
sorts of knowing winks in all sorts of directions, and ğŸ‘¢ off his
shoes, he strikes into a sharp but noiseless ğŸ˜¢ of a hornpipe right
over the â“‚ Turk's â“; and then, by a dexterous sleight, pitching
his ğŸ‘‘ up into the mizentop for a shelf, he goes down rollicking so
far at least as he remains visible from the deck, reversing all other
processions, by bringing up the ğŸŒ¹ with music. But ere stepping into
the cabin ğŸšª below, he pauses, ships a ğŸ†• face altogether, and,
then, independent, hilarious little Flask enters King Ahab's presence,
in the character of Abjectus, or the Slave.

It is not the least among the strange things bred by the intense
artificialness of ğŸŒŠ-usages, that while in the open air of the deck
some officers will, upon provocation, ğŸ‰‘ themselves boldly and
defyingly enough towards their commander; yet, âŒ to 1âƒ£, let those
very officers the next moment âŒ down to their customary dinner in that
same commander's cabin, and straightway their inoffensive, not to say
deprecatory and humble air towards him, as he sits at the â“ of
the table; this is marvellous, sometimes most comical. Wherefore this
difference? A problem? Perhaps not. To have been Belshazzar, King of
Babylon; and to have been Belshazzar, not haughtily but courteously,
therein certainly must have been some ğŸ‘» of mundane grandeur. But he
who in the rightly regal and ğŸ”‰ â™¥ presides over his own
ãŠ™ dinner-table of invited guests, that ğŸ‘¨'s unchallenged ğŸ¢
and dominion of individual influence for the time; that ğŸ‘¨'s royalty of
state transcends Belshazzar's, for Belshazzar was not the greatest. Who
has but once dined his friends, has tasted what it is to be Caesar. It
is a witchery of social czarship which there is no withstanding. Now,
if to this consideration you superadd the official supremacy of a
ğŸš¢-master, then, by inference, you will derive the cause of that
peculiarity of ğŸŒŠ-life just mentioned.

Over his ivory-inlaid table, Ahab presided like a ğŸ”‡, maned
ğŸŒŠ-lion on the white coral beach, surrounded by his warlike but ğŸ˜¯
deferential cubs. In his own proper ğŸ”§, each officer waited to be

there seemed not to lurk the smallest social arrogance. With 1âƒ£ mind,
their intent eyes all fastened upon the old ğŸ‘¨'s ğŸ‘…, as he carved

Another thing. Flask was the ğŸ”š person down at the dinner, and Flask

Now, Ahab and his 3âƒ£ mates formed what may be called the first table

In strange contrast to the hardly tolerable constraint and nameless

In this 1âƒ£ matter, Ahab seemed no exception to most American ğŸ³

CHAPTER 35. The Mast-â“.


It was during the more pleasant weather, that in due rotation with the
other seamen my first mast-â“ came round.

In most American whalemen the mast-heads are manned almost
simultaneously with the vessel's leaving her port; ğŸ˜³ though she may
have fifteen â“‚ miles, and more, to sail ere reaching her proper
cruising âš“. And if, after a 3âƒ£, 4âƒ£, or 5âƒ£ years' voyage
she is drawing nigh ğŸ  with anything empty in her--say, an empty vial
ğŸ˜³--then, her mast-heads are kept manned to the ğŸ”š; and not till her
skysail-poles sail in among the spires of the port, does she altogether
ğŸ†“ the hope of capturing 1âƒ£ ğŸ³ more.

Now, as the business of standing mast-heads, ashore or afloat, is a very
ancient and interesting 1âƒ£, let us in some measure expatiate here.
I ğŸ‰‘ it, that the earliest standers of mast-heads were the old
Egyptians; because, in all my researches, I find none prior to them.
For though their progenitors, the builders of Babel, must doubtless, by
their tower, have intended to ğŸŒ¹ the loftiest mast-â“ in all Asia,
or Africa either; yet (ere the final ğŸšš was put to it) as that great
ğŸ’ mast of theirs may be said to have gone by the board, in the ğŸ˜¨
gale of God's ğŸ’¢; therefore, we cannot ğŸƒ these Babel builders
priority over the Egyptians. And that the Egyptians were a nation of
mast-â“ standers, is an assertion based upon the general belief among
archaeologists, that the first pyramids were founded for astronomical
purposes: a theory singularly supported by the peculiar stair-like
formation of all 4âƒ£ sides of those edifices; whereby, with prodigious
long upliftings of their legs, those old astronomers were wont to ğŸŒ¹
to the apex, and ğŸ‘ out for ğŸ†• stars; ğŸ˜³ as the look-outs of a
modern ğŸš¢ ğŸ‘ out for a sail, or a ğŸ³ just bearing in sight. In
ğŸ‘¼ Stylites, the famous Christian hermit of old times, who built him
a lofty ğŸ’ pillar in the desert and spent the whole latter portion of
his life on its ğŸ”, hoisting his food from the âš“ with a
tackle; in him we have a remarkable instance of a dauntless
stander-of-mast-heads; who was not to be driven from his ğŸš‰ by fogs
or frosts, rain, hail, or sleet; but valiantly facing everything out to
the ğŸ”š, literally died at his ğŸš‰. Of modern standers-of-mast-heads
we have but a lifeless ğŸ‘—; mere ğŸ’, iron, and bronze ğŸš¹; who,
though well capable of facing out a stiff gale, are ğŸ˜¯ entirely
incompetent to the business of singing out upon discovering any strange
sight. There is Napoleon; who, upon the ğŸ” of the column of Vendome,
stands with arms folded, some 1âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ and fifty feet in the air;
careless, now, who rules the decks below; whether Louis Philippe, Louis
Blanc, or Louis the Devil. Great Washington, too, stands high aloft on
his towering main-mast in Baltimore, and like 1âƒ£ of Hercules' pillars,
his column marks that point of ğŸ‘¨ grandeur beyond which few mortals
will âŒ. Admiral Nelson, also, on a capstan of ğŸ”«-metal, stands his

London ğŸš¬, token is yet given that a ãŠ™ hero is there; for
where there is ğŸš¬, must be ğŸ”¥. But neither great Washington, nor
Napoleon, nor Nelson, will answer a 1âƒ£ hail from below, however
madly invoked to befriend by their counsels the distracted decks
upon which they gaze; however it may be surmised, that their spirits
penetrate through the thick haze of the future, and descry what shoals
and what rocks must be shunned.

It may seem unwarrantable to ğŸ‘« in any respect the mast-â“
standers of the land with those of the ğŸŒŠ; but that in truth it is

that in the early times of the ğŸ³ fishery, ere ships were regularly

who, upon descrying the ğŸ”™, gave ğŸ¶ to the ready-manned boats nigh

1âƒ£ proper mast-â“, that of a ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ at ğŸŒŠ. The 3âƒ£ mast-heads
are kept manned from sun-ğŸŒ¹ to sun-ğŸ‘—; the seamen taking their

In 1âƒ£ of those southern whalesmen, on a long 3âƒ£ or 4âƒ£ years'

Concerning all this, it is much to be deplored that the mast-heads of a

But if we Southern ğŸ³-fishers are not so snugly housed aloft as

Let me ğŸ’© a clean breast of it here, and frankly ğŸ‰‘ that I kept but

And let me in this ğŸš‰ movingly âš  you, ye ğŸš¢-owners of

"ğŸ‘‹ on, â“‚ deep and dark blue ğŸŒŠ, ğŸ‘‹! âŒ â“‚
blubber-hunters sweep over thee in vain."

Very often do the captains of such ships ğŸ‰‘ those absent-minded

"Why, â“‚ ğŸ‘¿," said a harpooneer to 1âƒ£ of these lads, "we've been

There is no life in thee, now, except that rocking life imparted by a

ğŸƒ your ğŸ¾ or ğŸš¹ an inch; slip your ğŸ“– at all; and your identity

CHAPTER 36. The ğŸ’©-Deck.

CHAPTER 41. Moby Dick.


I, Ishmael, was 1âƒ£ of that crew; my shouts had gone up with the rest;
my oath had been welded with theirs; and stronger I shouted, and more
did I ğŸ”¨ and clinch my oath, because of the ğŸ˜¨ in my soul. A
ğŸ˜ , ãŠ™, sympathetical feeling was in me; Ahab's quenchless feud
seemed mine. With greedy ears I learned the history of that murderous
monster against whom I and all the others had taken our oaths of
violence and revenge.

For some time past, though at intervals only, the unaccompanied,
ãŠ™ White ğŸ³ had haunted those uncivilized seas mostly
frequented by the Sperm ğŸ³ fishermen. But not all of them knew of his
existence; only a few of them, comparatively, had knowingly seen him;
while the number who as yet had actually and knowingly given battle to
him, was small indeed. For, owing to the large number of ğŸ³-cruisers;
the disorderly way they were sprinkled over the entire watery
circumference, many of them adventurously pushing their quest ğŸ”›
solitary latitudes, so as seldom or never for a whole twelvemonth or
more on a stretch, to encounter a 1âƒ£ news-telling sail of any sort;
the inordinate length of each separate voyage; the irregularity of the
times of sailing from ğŸ ; all these, with other circumstances, ğŸš‹
and indirect, long obstructed the spread through the whole ğŸ‘¨-wide
whaling-ğŸ¯ of the special individualizing tidings concerning Moby
Dick. It was hardly to be doubted, that several vessels reported to have
encountered, at such or such a time, or on such or such a ğŸ”,
a Sperm ğŸ³ of uncommon magnitude and malignity, which ğŸ³, after
doing great mischief to his assailants, had completely escaped them; to
some minds it was not an unfair presumption, I say, that the ğŸ³ in
â“ must have been no other than Moby Dick. Yet as of late the
Sperm ğŸ³ fishery had been marked by various and not unfrequent
instances of great ferocity, cunning, and malice in the monster
attacked; therefore it was, that those who by accident ignorantly gave
battle to Moby Dick; such hunters, perhaps, for the most ğŸ¢, were
content to ascribe the peculiar terror he bred, more, as it were, to
the perils of the Sperm ğŸ³ fishery at large, than to the individual
cause. In that way, mostly, the disastrous encounter between Ahab and
the ğŸ³ had hitherto been popularly regarded.

And as for those who, previously hearing of the White ğŸ³, by chance
caught sight of him; in the beginning of the thing they had every 1âƒ£ of
them, almost, as boldly and fearlessly lowered for him, as for any other
ğŸ³ of that species. But at length, such calamities did ensue in these
assaults--not restricted to sprained wrists and ankles, ğŸ˜• limbs, or
devouring amputations--but fatal to the ğŸ”š degree of fatality; those
repeated disastrous repulses, all accumulating and piling their terrors
upon Moby Dick; those things had gone far to shake the fortitude of many
brave hunters, to whom the story of the White ğŸ³ had eventually come.

Nor did ğŸ˜  rumors of all sorts ğŸ’£ to exaggerate, and ğŸ˜¯ the more
horrify the true histories of these deadly encounters. For not only do
fabulous rumors naturally ğŸŒ¹ out of the very body of all surprising
ğŸ˜¨ events,--as the smitten tree gives ğŸ» to its fungi; but, in
maritime life, far more than in that of terra firma, ğŸ˜  rumors abound,
wherever there is any adequate reality for them to cling to. And as the
ğŸŒŠ surpasses the land in this matter, so the ğŸ³ fishery surpasses
every other sort of maritime life, in the wonderfulness and fearfulness
of the rumors which sometimes circulate there. For not only are whalemen
as a body unexempt from that ignorance and superstitiousness hereditary
to all sailors; but of all sailors, they are by all odds the most
directly brought into ğŸ”— with whatever is appallingly astonishing
in the ğŸŒŠ; face to face they not only â™¥ its greatest marvels, but,
ğŸš¹ to jaw, ğŸƒ battle to them. Alone, in such remotest waters, that
though you sailed a â“‚ miles, and passed a â“‚ shores, you
would not come to any chiseled hearth-ğŸ’, or 0âƒ£ hospitable beneath
that ğŸ¢ of the sun; in such latitudes and longitudes, pursuing too
such a ğŸ“² as he does, the whaleman is wrapped by influences all
tending to ğŸ’© his fancy pregnant with many a mighty ğŸ».

No â“, then, that ever gathering ğŸ“– from the mere transit over
the widest watery spaces, the outblown rumors of the White ğŸ³ did
in the ğŸ”š incorporate with themselves all manner of morbid hints,
and half-formed foetal suggestions of supernatural agencies, which
eventually invested Moby Dick with ğŸ†• terrors unborrowed from anything
that visibly appears. So that in many cases such a panic did he finally
strike, that few who by those rumors, at least, had heard of the White
ğŸ³, few of those hunters were willing to encounter the perils of his
jaw.

But there were ğŸ˜¯ other and more vital practical influences at ğŸƒ.
Not ğŸ˜³ at the ğŸ day has the original prestige of the Sperm
ğŸ³, as fearfully distinguished from all other species of the
leviathan, died out of the minds of the whalemen as a body. There are
those this day among them, who, though ğŸ”‰ and courageous
enough in offering battle to the Greenland or Right ğŸ³, would
perhaps--either from professional inexperience, or incompetency, or
timidity, decline a contest with the Sperm ğŸ³; at any rate, there are
plenty of whalemen, especially among those whaling nations not sailing
under the American ğŸ, who have never hostilely encountered the Sperm
ğŸ³, but whose sole knowledge of the leviathan is restricted to
the ignoble monster primitively pursued in the North; seated on their
hatches, these ğŸš¹ will hearken with a childish fireside ğŸ˜Ÿ
and awe, to the ğŸ˜ , strange tales of Southern whaling. Nor is the
pre-eminent tremendousness of the great Sperm ğŸ³ anywhere more
feelingly comprehended, than on board of those prows which ğŸ™‡ him.

And as if the now tested reality of his might had in former
legendary times thrown its shadow before it; we find some ğŸ“–
naturalists--Olassen and Povelson--declaring the Sperm ğŸ³ not only to
be a consternation to every other creature in the ğŸŒŠ, but also to be so
incredibly ferocious as continually to be athirst for ğŸ‘¨ blood. Nor
ğŸ˜³ down to so late a time as Cuvier's, were these or almost similar
impressions effaced. For in his Natural History, the Baron himself
affirms that at sight of the Sperm ğŸ³, all ğŸŸ (sharks included) are
"struck with the most lively terrors," and "often in the precipitancy of
their flight ğŸ’¨ themselves against the rocks with such violence as to
cause instantaneous ğŸ”š." And however the general experiences in the
fishery may amend such reports as these; yet in their full terribleness,
ğŸ˜³ to the bloodthirsty item of Povelson, the superstitious belief in
them is, in some vicissitudes of their ğŸ“², revived in the minds of
the hunters.

So that overawed by the rumors and portents concerning him, not a few of
the fishermen recalled, in reference to Moby Dick, the earlier days
of the Sperm ğŸ³ fishery, when it was oftentimes hard to induce long
practised Right whalemen to ğŸš¢ in the perils of this ğŸ†• and daring
warfare; such ğŸš¹ protesting that although other leviathans might be
hopefully pursued, yet to ğŸ¶ and point lance at such an apparition
as the Sperm ğŸ³ was not for mortal ğŸ‘¨. That to attempt it, would
be inevitably to be torn into a quick eternity. On this â“, there are
some remarkable documents that may be consulted.

Nevertheless, some there were, who ğŸ˜³ in the face of these things
were ready to ğŸƒ ğŸ¶ to Moby Dick; and a ğŸ˜¯ greater number who,
chancing only to hear of him distantly and vaguely, without the
specific details of any certain calamity, and without superstitious
accompaniments, were sufficiently hardy not to flee from the battle if
offered.

1âƒ£ of the ğŸ˜  suggestions referred to, as at ğŸ”š coming to be linked
with the White ğŸ³ in the minds of the superstitiously inclined,
was the unearthly conceit that Moby Dick was ubiquitous; that he had
actually been encountered in opposite latitudes at 1âƒ£ and the same
ğŸ’“ of time.

Nor, credulous as such minds must have been, was this conceit altogether
without some faint Â® of superstitious probability. For as the secrets
of the currents in the seas have never yet been divulged, ğŸ˜³ to
the most erudite research; so the ãŠ™ ways of the Sperm ğŸ³
when beneath the ğŸŒ¹ remain, in great ğŸ¢, unaccountable to his
pursuers; and from time to time have originated the most curious and
contradictory speculations regarding them, especially concerning the
ãŠ™ modes whereby, after sounding to a great depth, he transports
himself with such vast swiftness to the most widely distant points.

It is a thing well known to both American and English ğŸ³-ships, and
as well a thing placed upon authoritative ğŸ“– years ago by Scoresby,
that some whales have been captured far north in the Pacific, in whose
bodies have been found the barbs of harpoons darted in the Greenland
seas. Nor is it to be gainsaid, that in some of these instances it has
been declared that the interval of time between the 2âƒ£ assaults could
not have exceeded very many days. Hence, by inference, it has been
believed by some whalemen, that the Nor' West Passage, so long a problem
to ğŸ‘¨, was never a problem to the ğŸ³. So that here, in the real
living experience of living ğŸš¹, the prodigies related in old times of
the inland Strello mountain in Portugal (near whose ğŸ” there was said
to be a lake in which the wrecks of ships floated up to the ğŸŒ¹);
and that ğŸ˜¯ more wonderful story of the Arethusa â›² near
Syracuse (whose waters were believed to have come from the Holy Land
by an ğŸš‡ passage); these fabulous narrations are almost fully
equalled by the realities of the whalemen.

Forced into familiarity, then, with such prodigies as these; and knowing
that after repeated, intrepid assaults, the White ğŸ³ had escaped
alive; it cannot be much matter of surprise that some whalemen should
âŒ ğŸ˜¯ further in their superstitions; declaring Moby Dick not only
ubiquitous, but immortal (for immortality is but ubiquity in time); that
though groves of spears should be planted in his flanks, he would ğŸ˜¯
swim away unharmed; or if indeed he should ever be made to spout thick
blood, such a sight would be but a ghastly deception; for again in
unensanguined billows hundreds of leagues away, his unsullied â›² would
once more be seen.

But ğŸ˜³ stripped of these supernatural surmisings, there was enough in
the earthly ğŸ’© and incontestable character of the monster to strike
the imagination with unwonted ğŸ¢. For, it was not so much his
uncommon bulk that so much distinguished him from other sperm whales,
but, as was elsewhere thrown out--a peculiar snow-white wrinkled
forehead, and a high, pyramidical white hump. These were his prominent
features; the tokens whereby, ğŸ˜³ in the limitless, uncharted seas, he
revealed his identity, at a long distance, to those who knew him.

The rest of his body was so streaked, and spotted, and marbled with
the same shrouded hue, that, in the ğŸ”š, he had gained his distinctive
appellation of the White ğŸ³; a ğŸ”‘, indeed, literally justified by
his vivid aspect, when seen gliding at high noon through a dark blue
ğŸŒŠ, leaving a milky-way wake of creamy âœ¨, all spangled with golden
gleamings.

Nor was it his unwonted magnitude, nor his remarkable hue, nor yet his
deformed ğŸ˜¦ jaw, that so much invested the ğŸ³ with natural terror,
as that ğŸ†•, ğŸ”‰ malignity which, according to specific
accounts, he had over and over again evinced in his assaults. More than
all, his treacherous retreats struck more of dismay than perhaps 0âƒ£
else. For, when swimming before his exulting pursuers, with every
apparent symptom of alarm, he had several times been known to ğŸ”§
round suddenly, and, bearing down upon them, either stave their boats to
splinters, or ğŸ them ğŸ”™ in consternation to their ğŸš¢.

Already several fatalities had attended his ğŸ¶. But though similar
disasters, however little bruited ashore, were by no means unusual
in the fishery; yet, in most instances, such seemed the White ğŸ³'s
infernal aforethought of ferocity, that every dismembering or ğŸ”š
that he caused, was not wholly regarded as having been inflicted by an
unintelligent agent.

Judge, then, to what pitches of inflamed, distracted ğŸ˜¡ the minds of
his more desperate hunters were impelled, when amid the chips of chewed
boats, and the sinking limbs of torn comrades, they swam out of the
white curds of the ğŸ³'s ğŸ˜¨ ğŸ’¢ into the serene, exasperating
sunlight, that smiled on, as if at a ğŸ» or a bridal.

His 3âƒ£ boats stove around him, and oars and ğŸš¹ both whirling in the
eddies; 1âƒ£ captain, seizing the ğŸ¶-ğŸ‘… from his ğŸ˜• ğŸ™‡, had

CHAPTER 42. The Whiteness of The ğŸ³.


What the white ğŸ³ was to Ahab, has been hinted; what, at times, he
was to me, as yet remains unsaid.

Aside from those more obvious considerations touching Moby Dick, which
could not but occasionally awaken in any ğŸ‘¨'s soul some alarm, there
was another thought, or rather vague, nameless horror concerning him,
which at times by its intensity completely overpowered all the rest; and
yet so ãŠ™ and well nigh ineffable was it, that I almost despair of
putting it in a comprehensible form. It was the whiteness of the ğŸ³
that above all things appalled me. But how can I hope to explain myself
here; and yet, in some dim, random way, explain myself I must, else all
these chapters might be 0âƒ£.

Though in many natural objects, whiteness refiningly enhances ğŸ‘, as
if imparting some special virtue of its own, as in marbles, japonicas,
and pearls; and though various nations have in some way recognised a
certain royal ğŸ¶ in this hue; ğŸ˜³ the barbaric, â“‚ old
kings of Pegu placing the title "Lord of the White Elephants" above all
their other magniloquent ascriptions of dominion; and the modern kings
of Siam unfurling the same snow-white quadruped in the royal standard;
and the Hanoverian ğŸ bearing the 1âƒ£ figure of a snow-white charger;
and the great Austrian Empire, Caesarian, heir to overlording Rome,
having for the imperial colour the same imperial hue; and though this
pre-ğŸ¶ in it applies to the ğŸ‘¨ ğŸƒ itself, ğŸ the white
ğŸ‘¨ ideal mastership over every dusky tribe; and though, besides, all
this, whiteness has been ğŸ˜³ made significant of gladness, for among
the Romans a white ğŸ’ marked a joyful day; and though in other mortal
sympathies and symbolizings, this same hue is made the emblem of many
touching, noble things--the innocence of brides, the benignity of age;
though among the ğŸ˜³ ğŸš¹ of America the ğŸ of the white belt
of ğŸ was the deepest pledge of honour; though in many climes,
whiteness typifies the majesty of Justice in the ermine of the Judge,
and contributes to the daily state of kings and queens drawn by
milk-white steeds; though ğŸ˜³ in the higher mysteries of the most
august religions it has been made the ğŸ”£ of the divine spotlessness
and ğŸ¢; by the Persian ğŸ”¥ worshippers, the white forked ğŸ”¥ being
held the holiest on the altar; and in the Greek mythologies, Great Jove
himself being made incarnate in a snow-white ğŸ·; and though to the
noble Iroquois, the midwinter sacrifice of the sacred White ğŸ¶ was
by far the holiest festival of their theology, that spotless, faithful
creature being held the purest envoy they could ğŸš¢ to the Great â™¥
with the annual tidings of their own fidelity; and though directly from

the 4âƒ£-and-twenty elders ğŸ» clothed in white before the great-white
ğŸš½, and the Holy 1âƒ£ that sitteth there white like wool; yet for all
these accumulated associations, with whatever is sweet, and honourable,
and sublime, there yet lurks an elusive something in the innermost idea
of this hue, which strikes more of panic to the soul than that redness
which affrights in blood.

This elusive quality it is, which causes the thought of whiteness, when
divorced from more kindly associations, and coupled with any object
ğŸ˜¨ in itself, to ğŸŒ¹ that terror to the furthest bounds.
Witness the white ğŸ‰‘ of the poles, and the white shark of the tropics;
what but their smooth, flaky whiteness makes them the transcendent

abhorrent mildness, ğŸ˜³ more loathsome than terrific, to the ğŸ”‡
gloating of their aspect. So that not the fierce-fanged ğŸ¯ in his
heraldic ğŸ° can so stagger courage as the white-shrouded ğŸ‰‘ or
shark.*


*With reference to the Polar ğŸ‰‘, it may possibly be urged by him
who would fain âŒ ğŸ˜¯ deeper into this matter, that it is not
the whiteness, separately regarded, which heightens the intolerable

with so unnatural a contrast. But ğŸ˜³ assuming all this to be true;
yet, were it not for the whiteness, you would not have that intensified

As for the white shark, the white gliding ghostliness of repose in that
creature, when beheld in his ordinary moods, strangely tallies with the

Bethink thee of the albatross, whence come those clouds of spiritual

imaginations? Not Coleridge first threw that spell; but God's great,
unflattering laureate, Nature.*


*I remember the first albatross I ever saw. It was during a prolonged
gale, in waters hard upon the Antarctic seas. From my forenoon âŒš
below, I ascended to the overclouded deck; and there, dashed upon the
main hatches, I saw a regal, feathery thing of unspotted whiteness, and
with a hooked, Roman ğŸ¶ sublime. At intervals, it arched forth

I assert, then, that in the wondrous bodily whiteness of the ğŸ¦

But how had the ãŠ™ thing been caught? Whisper it not, and I will

At ğŸ”š the Captain made a postman of it; tying a lettered, leathern

Most famous in our Western annals and Indian traditions is that of
the White Steed of the Prairies; a magnificent milk-white charger,
large-eyed, small-headed, bluff-chested, and with the dignity of a
â“‚ monarchs in his lofty, overscorning carriage. He was the
elected Xerxes of vast herds of ğŸ˜  horses, whose pastures in those
days were only fenced by the Rocky Mountains and the Alleghanies. At
their ğŸ”¥ â“ he westward trooped it like that chosen ğŸŒ  which
every evening leads on the hosts of âœ¨. The flashing ğŸš¿ of his

resplendent than gold and silver-beaters could have furnished him. A
most imperial and archangelical apparition of that unfallen, western
ğŸ‘¨, which to the eyes of the old trappers and hunters revived the
glories of those primeval times when Adam walked majestic as a god,
bluff-browed and fearless as this mighty steed. Whether marching amid
his aides and marshals in the van of countless cohorts that endlessly

bravest Indians he was the object of trembling reverence and awe. Nor

ğŸ´, that it was his spiritual whiteness chiefly, which so clothed him
with divineness; and that this divineness had that in it which, though
commanding worship, at the same time enforced a certain nameless terror.

But there are other instances where this whiteness loses all that
accessory and strange glory which invests it in the White Steed and
Albatross.

What is it that in the Albino ğŸ‘¨ so peculiarly repels and often shocks
the â™¥, as that sometimes he is loathed by his own kith and ğŸ‘ª! It
is that whiteness which invests him, a thing expressed by the ğŸ”‘
he bears. The Albino is as well made as other ğŸš¹--has no substantive
deformity--and yet this mere aspect of all-pervading whiteness makes him

Nor, in quite other aspects, does Nature in her least palpable but
not the less malicious agencies, ğŸ’£ to enlist among her forces

Nor, in some things, does the common, hereditary experience of all

ğŸ˜– the same snowy mantle round our phantoms; all ghosts rising in a
milk-white â˜--Yea, while these terrors seize us, let us add, that ğŸ˜³

Therefore, in his other moods, symbolize whatever â“‚ or gracious
thing he will by whiteness, no ğŸ‘¨ can deny that in its profoundest

But though without dissent this point be fixed, how is mortal ğŸ‘¨ to

by the citation of some of those instances wherein this thing of

to the ãŠ™ cause we seek?

Let us try. But in a matter like this, subtlety appeals to subtlety,
and without imagination no ğŸ‘¨ can âŒš another into these halls. And
though, doubtless, some at least of the imaginative impressions about

Why to the ğŸ‘¨ of untutored ideality, who happens to be but loosely

Or what is there apart from the traditions of dungeoned warriors and

Nor is it, altogether, the remembrance of her cathedral-toppling

I know that, to the common apprehension, this phenomenon of whiteness

First: The mariner, when drawing nigh the coasts of ğŸ‘½ lands, if by

ğŸƒ assures him he is ğŸ˜¯ off soundings; â™¥ and helm they both âŒ

ğŸ”™: To the native Indian of Peru, the continual sight of the

But â“‚ sayest, methinks that white-ğŸƒ chapter about whiteness is but

CHAPTER 43. Hark!

CHAPTER 45. The Affidavit.

In the sixth Christian ğŸ’¯ lived Procopius, a Christian magistrate

CHAPTER 46. Surmises.

CHAPTER 47. The Mat-Maker.


It was a cloudy, sultry afternoon; the seamen were lazily lounging

Queequeg and I were mildly employed weaving what is called a sword-mat,

I was the attendant or page of Queequeg, while busy at the mat. As I

"There she blows! there! there! there! she blows! she blows!"

"Where-away?"

"On the lee-beam, about 2âƒ£ miles off! a ğŸ« of them!"

CHAPTER 48. The First Lowering.

CHAPTER 49. The Hyena.


There are certain queer times and occasions in this strange mixed affair
we â˜ life when a ğŸ‘¨ takes this whole universe for a vast practical
joke, though the wit thereof he but dimly discerns, and more than
suspects that the joke is at nobody's expense but his own. However,
0âƒ£ dispirits, and 0âƒ£ seems worth while disputing. He bolts
down all events, all creeds, and beliefs, and persuasions, all hard
things visible and invisible, never mind how knobby; as an ostrich of
potent digestion gobbles down bullets and ğŸ”« flints. And as for small
difficulties and worryings, prospects of sudden disaster, peril of

illimitable ğŸ’´ Barrens and Salisbury Plains of the ğŸŒŠ, 2âƒ£ whaling
vessels descrying each other at the ends of the earth--off lone

I say, that under such circumstances these ships should not only
interchange hails, but come into ğŸ˜¯ closer, more friendly and
sociable ğŸ”—. And especially would this seem to be a matter of
ğŸƒ, in the ğŸš of vessels owned in 1âƒ£ seaport, and whose captains,
officers, and not a few of the ğŸš¹ are personally known to each other;
and consequently, have all sorts of dear domestic things to ğŸ‘ about.

For the long absent ğŸš¢, the outward-ğŸ¶, perhaps, has letters on
board; at any rate, she will be sure to let her have some papers of a
ğŸ“… a year or 2âƒ£ later than the ğŸ”š 1âƒ£ on her ğŸŒ and thumb-worn
files. And in return for that courtesy, the outward-bound ğŸš¢ would
receive the latest whaling intelligence from the cruising-âš“ to

in degree, all this will ğŸ“– true concerning whaling vessels crossing

are equally long absent from ğŸ . For 1âƒ£ of them may have received a
transfer of letters from some third, and now far remote vessel; and

Besides, they would exchange the whaling news, and have an agreeable

but likewise with all the peculiar congenialities arising from a common
pursuit and mutually shared privations and perils.

Nor would difference of country ğŸ’© any very essential difference;
that is, so long as both parties speak 1âƒ£ language, as is the ğŸš
with Americans and English. Though, to be sure, from the small number of
English whalers, such meetings do not very often occur, and when they
do occur there is too apt to be a sort of shyness between them; for your
Englishman is rather reserved, and your Yankee, he does not fancy that
sort of thing in anybody but himself. Besides, the English whalers
sometimes affect a kind of metropolitan superiority over the American
whalers; regarding the long, ğŸƒ Nantucketer, with his nondescript
provincialisms, as a sort of ğŸŒŠ-peasant. But where this superiority
in the English whalemen does really consist, it would be hard to say,
seeing that the Yankees in 1âƒ£ day, collectively, kill more whales than
all the English, collectively, in âŒ years. But this is a harmless
little foible in the English ğŸ³-hunters, which the Nantucketer does
not ğŸ‰‘ much to â™¥; probably, because he knows that he has a few
foibles himself.

So, then, we ğŸ“… that of all ships separately sailing the ğŸŒŠ, the
whalers have most reason to be sociable--and they are so. Whereas, some
merchant ships crossing each other's wake in the mid-Atlantic, will
oftentimes pass on without so much as a 1âƒ£ word of recognition,
mutually cutting each other on the high seas, like a ğŸ‘« of dandies in

each other's rig. As for ğŸš¹-of-War, when they chance to ğŸ˜† at ğŸŒŠ,
they first âŒ through such a ğŸš‹ of ğŸ’« bowings and scrapings, such

Slave-ships meeting, why, they are in such a prodigious hurry, they ğŸƒ
away from each other as ğŸ”œ as possible. And as for Pirates, when they
chance to cross each other's cross-bones, the first hail is--"How many
skulls?"--the same way that whalers hail--"How many barrels?" And that
â“ once answered, pirates straightway steer apart, for they are
infernal villains on both sides, and don't like to ğŸ“… overmuch of each
other's villanous likenesses.

But look at the godly, honest, unostentatious, hospitable, sociable,
ğŸ˜‡-and-easy whaler! What does the whaler do when she meets another
whaler in any sort of decent weather? She has a "GAM," a thing so
utterly ğŸ‘½ to all other ships that they never heard of the ğŸ”‘
ğŸ˜³; and if by chance they should hear of it, they only ğŸ˜ at it, and
ğŸ” gamesome stuff about "spouters" and "blubber-boilers," and such

that in boasting himself to be high lifted above a whaleman, in that

But what is a GAM? You might ğŸ» out your index-finger ğŸƒ up and
down the columns of dictionaries, and never find the word. Dr. Johnson
never attained to that erudition; Noah Webster's ark does not ğŸ“– it.
Nevertheless, this same expressive word has now for many years been in
constant use among some fifteen â“‚ true born Yankees. Certainly,
it needs a definition, and should be incorporated into the Lexicon. With
that âŒš, let me learnedly define it.

GAM. NOUN--A SOCIAL MEETING OF 2âƒ£ (OR MORE) WHALESHIPS, GENERALLY ON A
CRUISING-âš“; WHEN, AFTER EXCHANGING HAILS, THEY EXCHANGE VISITS BY
BOATS' CREWS; THE 2âƒ£ CAPTAINS REMAINING, FOR THE TIME, ON BOARD OF 1âƒ£
ğŸš¢, AND THE 2âƒ£ CHIEF MATES ON THE OTHER.

There is another little item about Gamming which must not be forgotten
here. All professions have their own little peculiarities of detail; so
has the ğŸ³ fishery. In a pirate, ğŸ‘¨-of-war, or slave ğŸš¢, when
the captain is rowed anywhere in his â›µ, he always sits in the ğŸ’©
sheets on a comfortable, sometimes cushioned ğŸ’º there, and often
steers himself with a pretty little milliner's tiller decorated with
â˜€ cords and ribbons. But the ğŸ³-â›µ has no ğŸ’º astern, no sofa of
that sort whatever, and no tiller at all. High times indeed, if whaling
captains were wheeled about the water on castors like gouty old aldermen
in patent chairs. And as for a tiller, the ğŸ³-â›µ never admits of
any such effeminacy; and therefore as in gamming a complete â›µ's crew
must ğŸƒ the ğŸš¢, and hence as the â›µ steerer or harpooneer is of
the number, that subordinate is the steersman upon the occasion, and
the captain, having no ğŸš‰ to ğŸ’º in, is pulled off to his ğŸ“²
all standing like a ğŸ’´ tree. And often you will ğŸ¶ that being
conscious of the eyes of the whole visible ğŸ‘¨ resting on him from
the sides of the 2âƒ£ ships, this standing captain is all alive to the
importance of sustaining his dignity by maintaining his legs. Nor is
this any very easy matter; for in his ğŸŒ¹ is the immense ğŸ˜Œ
steering oar hitting him now and then in the small of his ğŸ”™, the
after-oar reciprocating by rapping his knees in front. He is thus
completely wedged before and ğŸ’º, and can only ğŸ’¥ himself

pitch of the â›µ will often âŒ far to topple him, because length of
ğŸ¾ is 0âƒ£ without corresponding breadth. Merely ğŸ’© a
spread ğŸŸ of 2âƒ£ poles, and you cannot ğŸ» them up. Then, again,
it would never do in plain sight of the ğŸ‘¨'s riveted eyes, it would
never do, I say, for this straddling captain to be seen steadying
himself the slightest particle by catching ğŸ“– of anything with
his hands; indeed, as token of his entire, buoyant self-command, he
generally carries his hands in his trowsers' pockets; but perhaps being

Nevertheless there have occurred instances, well authenticated ones too,
where the captain has been known for an uncommonly critical moment or

hair, and ğŸ“– on there like grim ğŸ”š.



CHAPTER 54. The Town-Ho's Story.


(AS TOLD AT THE GOLDEN INN)


The Cape of ğŸ”‰ Hope, and all the watery region round about there, is
much like some noted 4âƒ£ corners of a great highway, where you ğŸ˜†
more travellers than in any other ğŸ¢.

It was not very long after speaking the Goney that another

*The ancient ğŸ³-ğŸ˜¢ upon first sighting a ğŸ³ from the mast-â“,
ğŸ˜¯ used by whalemen in hunting the famous Gallipagos terrapin.


For my humor's ğŸ¶, I shall preserve the ğŸ’¨ in which I once narrated

"Some 2âƒ£ years prior to my first learning the events which I am about

"Though no small passage was before her, yet, if the commonest chance
