"'Lakeman!--Buffalo! ğŸ™, what is a Lakeman, and where is Buffalo?'
said Don Sebastian, rising in his swinging mat of ğŸ€.

"On the eastern shore of our Lake Erie, Don; but--I crave your

"It was not more than a day or 2âƒ£ at the furthest after pointing

"Much this way had it been with the Town-Ho; so when her leak was found

"Now, as you well know, it is not seldom the ğŸš in this conventional
ğŸ‘¨ of ours--watery or otherwise; that when a person placed in command

"'Mr. Radney, I will not obey you. ğŸ‰‘ that ğŸ”¨ away, or look to

"For 3âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ and sixty miles, gentlemen, through the entire

CHAPTER 55. Of the Monstrous Pictures of Whales.


I shall ere long ğŸ”‘ to you as well as 1âƒ£ can without canvas,
something like the true form of the ğŸ³ as he actually appears to the
â™¥ of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the ğŸ³ is moored
alongside the ğŸ³-ğŸš¢ so that he can be fairly stepped upon there.
It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert to those
curious imaginary portraits of him which ğŸ˜³ down to the ğŸ day
confidently challenge the faith of the landsman. It is time to ğŸ‘— the
ğŸ‘¨ right in this matter, by proving such pictures of the ğŸ³ all
wrong.

It may be that the ğŸ”‘ source of all those pictorial delusions will
be found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian sculptures. For
ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times when on the marble
panellings of temples, the pedestals of statues, and on shields,
medallions, cups, and coins, the ğŸ¬ was drawn in scales of
chain-armor like Saladin's, and a helmeted â“ like St. George's; ever
since then has something of the same sort of license prevailed, not
only in most popular pictures of the ğŸ³, but in many scientific
presentations of him.

Now, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways purporting to
be the ğŸ³'s, is to be found in the famous cavern-pagoda of Elephanta,
in India. The Brahmins maintain that in the almost endless sculptures of
that immemorial pagoda, all the trades and pursuits, every conceivable
avocation of ğŸ‘¨, were prefigured ages before any of them actually came
into being. No â“ then, that in some sort our noble profession of
whaling should have been there shadowed forth. The Hindoo ğŸ³
referred to, occurs in a separate department of the wall, depicting the
incarnation of Vishnu in the form of leviathan, learnedly known as the
Matse Avatar. But though this sculpture is half ğŸ‘¨ and half ğŸ³, so
as only to ğŸƒ the ğŸ’© of the latter, yet that small section of him is
all wrong. It looks more like the tapering ğŸ’© of an anaconda, than the
broad palms of the true ğŸ³'s majestic flukes.

But âŒ to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian painter's
portrait of this ğŸŸ; for he succeeds no better than the antediluvian
Hindoo. It is Guido's picture of Perseus rescuing Andromeda from the
ğŸŒŠ-monster or ğŸ³. Where did Guido get the model of such a strange
creature as that? Nor does Hogarth, in painting the same scene in his
own "Perseus Descending," ğŸ’© out 1âƒ£ whit better. The huge corpulence
of that Hogarthian monster undulates on the ğŸŒ¹, scarcely drawing
1âƒ£ inch of water. It has a sort of howdah on its ğŸ”™, and its
distended tusked ğŸ‘„ into which the billows are rolling, might be
taken for the Traitors' Gate â­ from the Thames by water into the
Tower. Then, there are the Prodromus whales of old Scotch Sibbald, and
Jonah's ğŸ³, as depicted in the prints of old Bibles and the cuts of
old primers. What shall be said of these? As for the ğŸ“–-binder's ğŸ³
winding like a vine-stalk round the stock of a descending âš“--as
stamped and gilded on the backs and title-pages of many books both
old and ğŸ†•--that is a very picturesque but purely fabulous creature,
imitated, I ğŸ‰‘ it, from the like figures on antique vases.
Though universally denominated a ğŸ¬, I nevertheless â˜ this
ğŸ“–-binder's ğŸŸ an attempt at a ğŸ³; because it was so intended
when the device was first introduced. It was introduced by an old
Italian publisher somewhere about the 15th ğŸ’¯, during the Revival
of Learning; and in those days, and ğŸ˜³ down to a comparatively
late period, dolphins were popularly supposed to be a species of the
Leviathan.

In the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books you will
at times ğŸ˜† with very curious touches at the ğŸ³, where all manner
of spouts, jets d'eau, hot springs and cold, Saratoga and Baden-Baden,
come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain. In the title-page of the
original edition of the "Advancement of Learning" you will find some
curious whales.

But quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at those
pictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific delineations,
by those who know. In old Harris's collection of voyages there are some
plates of whales extracted from a Dutch ğŸ“– of voyages, A.D. 1671,
entitled "A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in the ğŸš¢ Jonas in the
ğŸ³, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master." In 1âƒ£ of those plates the
whales, like great rafts of logs, are represented lying among ğŸ‡-isles,
with white bears ğŸƒ over their living backs. In another ğŸš, the
prodigious blunder is made of representing the ğŸ³ with perpendicular
flukes.

Then again, there is an imposing quarto, written by 1âƒ£ Captain Colnett,
a ğŸš‰ Captain in the English navy, entitled "A Voyage round Cape ğŸº
into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending the Spermaceti ğŸ³
Fisheries." In this ğŸ“– is an outline purporting to be a "Picture of
a Physeter or Spermaceti ğŸ³, drawn by ğŸš from 1âƒ£ killed on the

To ğŸ¶ but 1âƒ£ thing about it, let me say that it has an â™¥ which

Nor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History for

mistake. Look at that popular ğŸƒ "Goldsmith's Animated Nature." In the

Then, again, in 1825, Bernard Germain, Count de Lacepede, a great
naturalist, published a scientific systemized ğŸ³ ğŸ“–, wherein are

But the placing of the ğŸ‘‘-sheaf to all this blundering business was

those Chinese are, many queer cups and saucers inform us.

As for the ğŸ -painters' whales seen in the streets hanging over the
shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them? They are generally

on 3âƒ£ or 4âƒ£ sailor tarts, that is whaleboats full of mariners:
their deformities floundering in seas of blood and blue ğŸ”‘.

But these manifold mistakes in depicting the ğŸ³ are not so very
surprising after all. Consider! Most of the scientific drawings have

drawing of a wrecked ğŸš¢, with ğŸ˜• ğŸ”™, would correctly represent
the noble animal itself in all its undashed pride of hull and spars.
Though elephants have stood for their full-lengths, the living Leviathan
has never yet fairly floated himself for his portrait. The living ğŸ³,
in his full majesty and significance, is only to be seen at ğŸŒŠ in
unfathomable waters; and afloat the vast bulk of him is out of sight,
like a launched ğŸ¶-of-battle ğŸš¢; and out of that element it is a
thing eternally impossible for mortal ğŸ‘¨ to hoist him bodily into the

ğŸš of 1âƒ£ of those ğŸ†• sucking whales hoisted to a ğŸš¢'s deck, such
is then the outlandish, eel-like, limbered, varying shape of him, that
his precise ğŸš§ the devil himself could not âŒš.

But it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded
ğŸ³, accurate hints may be derived touching his true form. Not at all.
For it is 1âƒ£ of the more curious things about this Leviathan, that
his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape. Though Jeremy

his executors, correctly conveys the idea of a burly-browed utilitarian

yet 0âƒ£ of this kind could be inferred from any leviathan's

of the ğŸ³ bears the same relation to the fully invested and padded
animal as the insect does to the chrysalis that so roundingly envelopes
it. This peculiarity is strikingly evinced in the â“, as in some
ğŸ¢ of this ğŸ“– will be incidentally shown. It is also very curiously
displayed in the side 5âƒ£, the bones of which almost exactly answer to
the bones of the ğŸ‘¨ ğŸš¹, minus only the thumb. This 5âƒ£ has 4âƒ£
regular bone-fingers, the index, â™¥, â˜, and little finger. But
all these are permanently lodged in their fleshy covering, as the ğŸ‘¨
fingers in an artificial covering. "However recklessly the ğŸ³ may
sometimes serve us," said humorous Stubb 1âƒ£ day, "he can never be truly
said to handle us without mittens."

For all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it, you must needs
conclude that the great Leviathan is that 1âƒ£ creature in the ğŸ‘¨
which must remain unpainted to the ğŸ”š. True, 1âƒ£ portrait may ğŸ’¥
the ğŸ¶ much nearer than another, but none can ğŸ’¥ it with any very

which you can derive ğŸ˜³ a tolerable idea of his living contour, is
by going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you ğŸƒ no small risk of
being eternally stove and sunk by him. Wherefore, it seems to me you had
best not be too fastidious in your curiosity touching this Leviathan.



CHAPTER 56. Of the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales, and the True
Pictures of Whaling Scenes.


In ğŸ”— with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly
tempted here to enter upon those ğŸ˜¯ more monstrous stories of
them which are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,
especially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, etc. But I pass
that matter by.

I know of only 4âƒ£ published outlines of the great Sperm ğŸ³;
Colnett's, Huggins's, Frederick Cuvier's, and Beale's. In the previous
chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to. Huggins's is far
better than theirs; but, by great odds, Beale's is the best. All Beale's
drawings of this ğŸ³ are ğŸ”‰, excepting the â™¥ figure in the
picture of 3âƒ£ whales in various attitudes, capping his ğŸ”™
chapter. His frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales, though no

admirably correct and life-like in its general effect. Some of the Sperm
ğŸ³ drawings in J. Ross Browne are pretty correct in contour; but they
are wretchedly engraved. That is not his fault though.

Of the Right ğŸ³, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby; but they
are drawn on too small a ğŸš to convey a desirable impression. He has
but 1âƒ£ picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad deficiency, because
it is by such pictures only, when at all well done, that you can derive
anything like a truthful idea of the living ğŸ³ as seen by his living
hunters.

But, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in some details
not the most correct, presentations of whales and whaling scenes to
be anywhere found, are 2âƒ£ large French engravings, well executed,
and taken from paintings by 1âƒ£ Garnery. Respectively, they represent
attacks on the Sperm and Right ğŸ³. In the first engraving a noble
Sperm ğŸ³ is depicted in full majesty of might, just risen beneath
the â›µ from the profundities of the ğŸŒŠ, and bearing high in the air
upon his ğŸ”™ the terrific wreck of the stoven planks. The ğŸ™‡ of
the â›µ is partially unbroken, and is drawn just balancing upon
the monster's ğŸ”™; and standing in that ğŸ™‡, for that 1âƒ£ 1âƒ£
incomputable ğŸ’“ of time, you behold an oarsman, half shrouded by the
incensed boiling spout of the ğŸ³, and in the act of leaping, as if
from a precipice. The action of the whole thing is wonderfully ğŸ”‰ and
true. The half-emptied ğŸ¶-ğŸ›€ floats on the whitened ğŸŒŠ; the wooden
poles of the spilled harpoons obliquely bob in it; the heads of the
swimming crew are ğŸ˜• about the ğŸ³ in contrasting expressions
of affright; while in the black stormy distance the ğŸš¢ is bearing down
upon the scene. Serious fault might be found with the anatomical details
of this ğŸ³, but let that pass; since, for the life of me, I could not
ğŸƒ so ğŸ”‰ a 1âƒ£.

In the ğŸ”™ engraving, the â›µ is in the act of drawing alongside
the barnacled flank of a large ğŸƒ Right ğŸ³, that rolls his black
weedy bulk in the ğŸŒŠ like some mossy rock-slide from the Patagonian
cliffs. His jets are erect, full, and black like soot; so that from so
abounding a ğŸš¬ in the chimney, you would think there must be a brave
supper cooking in the great bowels below. ğŸŒŠ fowls are pecking at the
small crabs, ğŸš-ğŸŸ, and other ğŸŒŠ candies and maccaroni, which the
Right ğŸ³ sometimes carries on his pestilent ğŸ”™. And all the while
the thick-lipped leviathan is rushing through the deep, leaving tons of

admirable artistic contrast, is the glassy ğŸ˜³ of a ğŸŒŠ becalmed, the
drooping unstarched sails of the powerless ğŸš¢, and the inert mass of
a dead ğŸ³, a conquered fortress, with the ğŸ of capture lazily
hanging from the ğŸ³-pole inserted into his spout-hole.

Who Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not. But my life for it he
was either practically conversant with his subject, or else marvellously
tutored by some experienced whaleman. The French are the lads for
painting action. âŒ and gaze upon all the paintings of Europe, and
where will you find such a gallery of living and breathing commotion
on canvas, as in that triumphal hall at Versailles; where the beholder
fights his way, pell-mell, through the consecutive great battles of
France; where every sword seems a ğŸ’“ of the Northern Lights, and the
successive armed kings and Emperors ğŸ’¨ by, like a ğŸ‘¢ of crowned
centaurs? Not wholly unworthy of a ğŸš‰ in that gallery, are these ğŸŒŠ
battle-pieces of Garnery.

The natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness of
things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings and engravings
they have of their whaling scenes. With not 1âƒ£ tenth of England's
experience in the fishery, and not the thousandth ğŸ¢ of that of the
Americans, they have nevertheless furnished both nations with the only

the ğŸ³ ğŸƒ. For the most ğŸ¢, the English and American ğŸ³
draughtsmen seem entirely content with presenting the mechanical outline

and grapnels; and with the microscopic diligence of a Leuwenhoeck

magnified Arctic snow crystals. I mean no disparagement to the excellent
voyager (I honour him for a veteran), but in so important a matter it
was certainly an oversight not to have procured for every crystal a
sworn affidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of the Peace.

In addition to those ğŸ†— engravings from Garnery, there are 2âƒ£ other

CHAPTER 58. Brit.

CHAPTER 60. The ğŸ¶.


With reference to the whaling scene ğŸ”œ to be described, as well as

The ğŸ¶ originally used in the fishery was of the best hemp, slightly
vapoured with tar, not impregnated with it, as in the ğŸš of ordinary
ropes; for while tar, as ordinarily used, makes the hemp more pliable to

may ğŸƒ it compactness and gloss.

Of late years the Manilla rope has in the American fishery almost
entirely superseded hemp as a material for ğŸ³-lines; for, though not
so durable as hemp, it is stronger, and far more soft and elastic; and
I will add (since there is an aesthetics in all things), is much more
handsome and becoming to the â›µ, than hemp. Hemp is a dusky, dark
fellow, a sort of Indian; but Manilla is as a golden-haired Circassian
to behold.

The ğŸ³-ğŸ¶ is only 2âƒ£-thirds of an inch in thickness. At first

CHAPTER 62. The ğŸ’¨.


A word concerning an incident in the ğŸ”š chapter.

According to the invariable ğŸ›ƒ of the fishery, the ğŸ³-â›µ pushes
off from the ğŸš¢, with the headsman or ğŸ³-killer as temporary
steersman, and the harpooneer or ğŸ³-fastener pulling the foremost
oar, the 1âƒ£ known as the harpooneer-oar. Now it needs a strong, nervous
arm to strike the first iron into the ğŸŸ; for often, in what is called
a long ğŸ’¨, the ğŸ”‰ implement has to be flung to the distance of
twenty or thirty feet. But however prolonged and exhausting the ğŸ¶,
the harpooneer is expected to ğŸ”§ his oar meanwhile to the uttermost;
indeed, he is expected to ğŸ‘— an example of superhuman activity to the
rest, not only by incredible rowing, but by repeated loud and intrepid
exclamations; and what it is to keep shouting at the ğŸ” of 1âƒ£'s
compass, while all the other muscles are strained and half started--what
that is none know but those who have tried it. For 1âƒ£, I cannot bawl
very heartily and ğŸƒ very recklessly at 1âƒ£ and the same time. In this
straining, bawling state, then, with his ğŸ”™ to the ğŸŸ, all at once
the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting ğŸ˜¢--"ğŸ» up, and ğŸƒ it
to him!" He now has to drop and secure his oar, ğŸ”§ round on his

strength may remain, he essays to pitch it somehow into the ğŸ³. No
â“, taking the whole ğŸ¯ of whalemen in a body, that out of fifty
fair chances for a ğŸ’¨, not 5âƒ£ are successful; no â“ that so many
hapless harpooneers are madly cursed and disrated; no â“ that some

some sperm whalemen are absent 4âƒ£ years with 4âƒ£ barrels; no â“
that to many ğŸš¢ owners, whaling is but a losing ğŸ˜Ÿ; for it is the
harpooneer that makes the voyage, and if you ğŸ‰‘ the breath out of his
body how can you ğŸ» to find it there when most wanted!

Again, if the ğŸ’¨ be successful, then at the ğŸ”™ critical ğŸ’“,
that is, when the ğŸ³ starts to ğŸƒ, the boatheader and harpooneer

the headsman, the chief officer of the little craft, takes his proper

Now, I ğŸ˜Ÿ not who maintains the contrary, but all this is both foolish
and unnecessary. The headsman should stay in the bows from first to
ğŸ”š; he should both ğŸ’¨ the harpoon and the lance, and no rowing
whatever should be expected of him, except under circumstances obvious
to any fisherman. I know that this would sometimes involve a slight loss
of speed in the ğŸ¶; but long experience in various whalemen of more
than 1âƒ£ nation has convinced me that in the vast majority of failures
in the fishery, it has not by any means been so much the speed of the
ğŸ³ as the before described exhaustion of the harpooneer that has
caused them.

To insure the greatest efficiency in the ğŸ’¨, the harpooneers of this
ğŸ‘¨ must start to their feet from out of idleness, and not from out of
toil.



CHAPTER 63. The Crotch.


Out of the trunk, the branches ğŸŒ¹; out of them, the twigs. So, in
productive subjects, ğŸŒ¹ the chapters.

The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent ğŸ¶.
It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some 2âƒ£ feet in length, which
is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale near the ğŸ™‡,
for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden extremity of the
harpoon, whose other naked, barbed ğŸ”š slopingly projects from the ğŸ™‡.
Thereby the weapon is instantly at ğŸš¹ to its hurler, who snatches it
up as readily from its rest as a backwoodsman swings his rifle from

respectively called the first and ğŸ”™ irons.

But these 2âƒ£ harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with
the ğŸ¶; the object being this: to ğŸ’¨ them both, if possible, 1âƒ£
instantly after the other into the same ğŸ³; so that if, in the coming

doubling of the chances. But it very often happens that owing to the
instantaneous, violent, convulsive ğŸƒ of the ğŸ³ upon receiving

Nevertheless, as the ğŸ”™ iron is already connected with the ğŸ¶,
and the ğŸ¶ is ğŸƒ, hence that weapon must, at all events, be
anticipatingly tossed out of the â›µ, somehow and somewhere; else the
most ğŸ˜¨ jeopardy would involve all hands. Tumbled into the water,
it accordingly is in such cases; the ğŸ†“ coils of ğŸ“¦ ğŸ¶ (mentioned
in a preceding chapter) making this feat, in most instances, prudently
practicable. But this critical act is not always unattended with the
saddest and most fatal casualties.

Furthermore: you must know that when the ğŸ”™ iron is thrown
overboard, it thenceforth becomes a dangling, sharp-edged terror,
skittishly curvetting about both â›µ and ğŸ³, entangling the lines,
or cutting them, and making a prodigious ğŸŒ  in all directions.
Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until the ğŸ³ is
fairly captured and a corpse.

Consider, now, how it must be in the ğŸš of 4âƒ£ boats all engaging
1âƒ£ unusually strong, active, and knowing ğŸ³; when owing to these

with several harpoons to ğŸ™‡ on to the ğŸ¶ should the first 1âƒ£
be ineffectually darted without recovery. All these particulars are

Stubb's ğŸ³ had been killed some distance from the ğŸš¢. It was

*A little item may as well be related here. The strongest and most

CHAPTER 65. The ğŸ³ as a ğŸ‘.


That mortal ğŸ‘¨ should ğŸƒ upon the creature that feeds his lamp, and,

It is upon ğŸ“–, that 3âƒ£ centuries ago the ğŸ‘… of the Right
ğŸ³ was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large

court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce to be

ğŸ³. Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered ğŸ†— eating. The
â™¥ is made into balls about the size of billiard balls, and being well
seasoned and spiced might be taken for ğŸ¢-balls or veal balls.
The old monks of Dunfermline were very fond of them. They had a great
porpoise grant from the ğŸ”.

The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the ğŸ³ would by all

But what further depreciates the ğŸ³ as a civilized ğŸ‘, is his

In the ğŸš of a small Sperm ğŸ³ the brains are accounted a ğŸ†— ğŸ‘.

CHAPTER 66. The Shark Massacre.


When in the Southern Fishery, a captured Sperm ğŸ³, after long and
ğŸ˜© toil, is brought alongside late at night, it is not, as a general

that all goes well.

But sometimes, especially upon the ğŸ¶ in the Pacific, this plan will

In most other parts of the ğŸŒŠ, however, where these ğŸŸ do not so

Nevertheless, upon Stubb setting the âš“-âŒš after his supper was

1âƒ£ of these sharks almost took poor Queequeg's ğŸš¹ off, when he tried

*The whaling-â™  used for cutting-in is made of the very best steel;
is about the bigness of a ğŸ‘¨'s spread ğŸš¹; and in general shape,

the ğŸ˜¦. This weapon is always kept as sharp as possible; and when
being used is occasionally honed, just like a razor. In its socket, a
stiff pole, from twenty to thirty feet long, is inserted for a handle.


"Queequeg no ğŸ˜Ÿ what god made him shark," said the ğŸº, agonizingly
lifting his ğŸš¹ up and down; "wedder Fejee god or Nantucket god; but de

CHAPTER 67. Cutting In.


It was a Saturday night, and such a Sabbath as followed! âŒ officio
professors of Sabbath breaking are all whalemen. The ivory Pequod was

CHAPTER 68. The Blanket.


I have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject, the skin of
the ğŸ³. I have had controversies about it with experienced whalemen
afloat, and learned naturalists ashore. My original opinion remains
unchanged; but it is only an opinion.

The â“ is, what and where is the skin of the ğŸ³? Already you
know what his blubber is. That blubber is something of the consistence
of ğŸ , ğŸ”š-grained beef, but tougher, more elastic and compact, and
ranges from 8âƒ£ or âŒ to twelve and fifteen inches in thickness.

Now, however preposterous it may at first seem to ğŸ‘ of any creature's
skin as being of that sort of consistence and thickness, yet in point
of fact these are no arguments against such a presumption; because you
cannot ğŸ”¥ any other dense enveloping layer from the ğŸ³'s body but
that same blubber; and the outermost enveloping layer of any animal, if
reasonably dense, what can that be but the skin? True, from the unmarred
dead body of the ğŸ³, you may scrape off with your ğŸš¹ an infinitely

of isinglass, only it is almost as flexible and soft as satin; that is,
previous to being dried, when it not only contracts and thickens, but
becomes rather hard and brittle. I have several such dried bits, which
I use for marks in my ğŸ³-books. It is transparent, as I said before;
and being laid upon the printed page, I have sometimes pleased myself
with fancying it exerted a magnifying influence. At any rate, it is
pleasant to Â® about whales through their own spectacles, as you may
say. But what I am driving at here is this. That same infinitely thin,

ğŸ³, is not so much to be regarded as the skin of the creature, as
the skin of the skin, so to speak; for it were simply ridiculous to say,
that the proper skin of the tremendous ğŸ³ is thinner and more tender
than the skin of a ğŸ†•-born ğŸ‘¶. But no more of this.

Assuming the blubber to be the skin of the ğŸ³; then, when this skin,
as in the ğŸš of a very large Sperm ğŸ³, will ğŸ» the bulk of 1âƒ£

and not the entire â™¥ of the ğŸ°; some idea may hence be had

In life, the visible ğŸŒ¹ of the Sperm ğŸ³ is not the least among
the many marvels he presents. Almost invariably it is all over obliquely

A word or 2âƒ£ more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of
the ğŸ³. It has already been said, that it is stript from him in long

whereas, like ğŸ‘¨, the ğŸ³ has lungs and warm blood. Freeze his blood,

It does seem to me, that herein we ğŸ“… the rare virtue of a strong

CHAPTER 70. The Sphynx.

ğŸš¹ in ğŸš¹, ğŸš¢ and breeze blew on; but the breeze came faster than

CHAPTER 72. The ğŸ‘¿-Rope.


In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a ğŸ³, there
is much ğŸƒ ğŸ”™ and forwards among the crew. Now hands are
wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there. There is no staying
in any 1âƒ£ ğŸš‰; for at 1âƒ£ and the same time everything has to be done
everywhere. It is much the same with him who endeavors the description

that upon first breaking âš“ in the ğŸ³'s ğŸ”™, the blubber-ğŸ‘®
was inserted into the original hole there cut by the spades of the

get fixed in that hole? It was inserted there by my particular friend

cases, circumstances require that the harpooneer shall remain on the
ğŸ³ till the whole flensing or stripping operation is concluded. The
ğŸ³, be it observed, lies almost entirely submerged, excepting the
immediate parts operated upon. So down there, some âŒ feet below the
ğŸ˜³ of the deck, the poor harpooneer flounders about, half on the

Being the ğŸº's bowsman, that is, the person who pulled the ğŸ™‡-oar

down there in the ğŸŒŠ, by what is technically called in the fishery

It was a humorously perilous business for both of us. For, before we

and honour demanded, that instead of cutting the cord, it should drag

Queequeg was my own inseparable ğŸ‘« brother; nor could I any way get

So strongly and metaphysically did I conceive of my ğŸ¢ then, that

2âƒ£; that my ğŸ˜‡ will had received a mortal wound; and that another's

*The ğŸ‘¿-rope is found in all whalers; but it was only in the Pequod
that the ğŸ‘¿ and his holder were ever tied together. This improvement

in â™£ to afford the imperilled harpooneer the strongest possible

I have hinted that I would often jerk poor Queequeg from between the
ğŸ³ and the ğŸš¢--where he would occasionally fall, from the incessant

And right in among those sharks was Queequeg; who often pushed them

Nevertheless, it may well be believed that since they have such a

CHAPTER 79. The Prairie.

Now, this occasional inevitable sinking of the recently killed Sperm
ğŸ³ is a very curious thing; nor has any fisherman yet adequately
accounted for it. Usually the dead Sperm ğŸ³ floats with great
buoyancy, with its side or belly considerably elevated above the
ğŸŒ¹. If the only whales that thus sank were old, meagre, and
ğŸ˜•-hearted creatures, their pads of lard diminished and all their
bones ğŸ”‰ and rheumatic; then you might with some reason assert that
this sinking is caused by an uncommon specific gravity in the ğŸŸ so
sinking, consequent upon this absence of buoyant matter in him. But it
is not so. For ğŸ†• whales, in the highest health, and swelling with
noble aspirations, prematurely cut off in the warm ğŸŒ¼ and May of
life, with all their panting lard about them; ğŸ˜³ these brawny, buoyant
heroes do sometimes sink.

Be it said, however, that the Sperm ğŸ³ is far less liable to this
accident than any other species. Where 1âƒ£ of that sort âŒ down, twenty
Right Whales do. This difference in the species is no â“ imputable in
no small degree to the greater quantity of bone in the Right ğŸ³;
his Venetian blinds alone sometimes weighing more than a ton; from this
incumbrance the Sperm ğŸ³ is wholly ğŸ˜‡. But there are instances
where, after the lapse of many hours or several days, the sunken ğŸ³
again rises, more buoyant than in life. But the reason of this
is obvious. Gases are generated in him; he swells to a prodigious
magnitude; becomes a sort of animal ğŸˆ. A ğŸ¶-of-battle ğŸš¢ could
hardly keep him under then. In the Shore Whaling, on soundings, among
the Bays of ğŸ†• Zealand, when a Right ğŸ³ gives token of sinking, they
fasten buoys to him, with plenty of rope; so that when the body has gone
down, they know where to look for it when it shall have ascended again.

It was not long after the sinking of the body that a ğŸ˜¢ was heard from
the Pequod's mast-heads, announcing that the Jungfrau was again lowering
her boats; though the only spout in sight was that of a 5âƒ£-ğŸ”™,
belonging to the species of uncapturable whales, because of its

Oh! many are the 5âƒ£-Backs, and many are the Dericks, my friend.



CHAPTER 82. The Honour and Glory of Whaling.


There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the true
method.

The more I dive into this matter of whaling, and push my researches up
to the very â›²-â“ of it so much the more am I impressed with its
great honourableness and antiquity; and especially when I find so many

have shed ğŸ¶ upon it, I am transported with the reflection

fraternity.

The gallant Perseus, a ğŸ‘¦ of Jupiter, was the first whaleman; and
to the eternal honour of our ğŸ“² be it said, that the first ğŸ³
attacked by our brotherhood was not killed with any sordid intent. Those

knows the ğŸ†— story of Perseus and Andromeda; how the lovely Andromeda,
the ğŸ‘§ of a king, was tied to a rock on the ğŸŒŠ-coast, and as
Leviathan was in the very act of carrying her off, Perseus, the prince

achieved by the best harpooneers of the ğŸ day; inasmuch as this
Leviathan was slain at the very first ğŸ’¨. And let no ğŸ‘¨ â“ this
Arkite story; for in the ancient Joppa, now Jaffa, on the Syrian coast,
in 1âƒ£ of the Pagan temples, there stood for many ages the vast skeleton
of a ğŸ³, which the city's legends and all the inhabitants asserted to
be the identical bones of the monster that Perseus slew. When the Romans
took Joppa, the same skeleton was carried to Italy in ğŸ˜¤. What
seems most singular and suggestively important in this story, is this:
it was from Joppa that Jonah ğŸ‘— sail.

Akin to the adventure of Perseus and Andromeda--indeed, by some supposed

ğŸ‰ of the ğŸŒŠ," saith Ezekiel; hereby, plainly meaning a ğŸ³;

Let not the modern paintings of this scene mislead us; for though

ğŸ“– this so-called ğŸ‰ no other than the great Leviathan himself. In

Whether to ğŸ‰‘ Hercules among us or not, concerning this I long

CHAPTER 83. Jonah Historically Regarded.


Reference was made to the historical story of Jonah and the ğŸ³ in the

1âƒ£ old ğŸ-Harbor whaleman's chief reason for questioning the Hebrew

ğŸ³ is toothless.

Another reason which ğŸ-Harbor (he went by that ğŸ”‘) urged for his

How is that?

But was there no other way for the ğŸ³ to land the prophet within that

But all these foolish arguments of old ğŸ-Harbor only evinced his

some 3âƒ£ centuries ago, an English traveller in old Harris's Voyages,
speaks of a Turkish Mosque built in honour of Jonah, in which Mosque was
a miraculous lamp that burnt without any oil.



CHAPTER 84. Pitchpoling.


To ğŸ’© them ğŸƒ easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are
anointed; and for much the same purpose, some whalers perform an

to be doubted that as such a procedure can do no harm, it may possibly

disappeared, took more than customary pains in that occupation; crawling

the craft's bald keel. He seemed to be ğŸƒ in obedience to some
particular presentiment. Nor did it remain unwarranted by the event.

Towards noon whales were raised; but so ğŸ”œ as the ğŸš¢ sailed down to
them, they turned and fled with swift precipitancy; a ğŸ˜• flight,
as of Cleopatra's barges from Actium.

Nevertheless, the boats pursued, and Stubb's was foremost. By great
ğŸ˜“, Tashtego at ğŸ”š succeeded in planting 1âƒ£ iron; but the
stricken ğŸ³, without at all sounding, ğŸ˜¯ continued his horizontal

to haul the â›µ up to his flank was impossible, he swam so fast and
ğŸ˜ . What then remained?

Of all the wondrous devices and dexterities, the sleights of ğŸš¹ and
countless subtleties, to which the veteran whaleman is so often forced,
none ğŸ” that ğŸ†— manoeuvre with the lance called pitchpoling. Small
sword, or broad sword, in all its exercises boasts 0âƒ£ like it. It
is only indispensable with an inveterate ğŸƒ ğŸ³; its â“‚
fact and feature is the wonderful distance to which the long lance is
accurately darted from a violently rocking, jerking â›µ, under extreme

feet in length; the staff is much slighter than that of the harpoon,
and also of a lighter material--ğŸ’´. It is furnished with a small rope
called a warp, of considerable length, by which it can be hauled ğŸ”™ to
the ğŸš¹ after darting.

But before going further, it is important to ğŸ¶ here, that though
the harpoon may be pitchpoled in the same way with the lance, yet it
is seldom done; and when done, is ğŸ˜¯ less frequently successful,
on account of the greater weight and inferior length of the harpoon as
compared with the lance, which in effect become serious drawbacks. As a
general thing, therefore, you must first get fast to a ğŸ³, before any
pitchpoling comes into ğŸƒ.

Look now at Stubb; a ğŸ‘¨ who from his humorous, deliberate coolness and

flying â›µ; wrapt in fleecy âœ¨, the towing ğŸ³ is forty feet ahead.
Handling the long lance lightly, glancing twice or thrice ğŸ”› its

grasp, leaving the rest unobstructed. Then holding the lance full before
his waistband's â™¥, he levels it at the ğŸ³; when, covering
him with it, he steadily depresses the ğŸ-ğŸ”š in his ğŸš¹, thereby
elevating the point till the weapon stands fairly balanced upon his
ğŸ€, fifteen feet in the air. He minds you somewhat of a juggler,
balancing a long staff on his chin. Next moment with a rapid, nameless

sparkling water, he now spouts ğŸ˜³ blood.

"That drove the spigot out of him!" cried Stubb. "'Tis July's immortal
Fourth; all fountains must ğŸƒ wine today! Would now, it were old

Again and again to such gamesome ğŸ‘, the dexterous ğŸ’¨ is repeated,

CHAPTER 85. The â›².


That for 6âƒ£ â“‚ years--and no 1âƒ£ knows how many millions of ages
before--the great whales should have been spouting all over the ğŸŒŠ,
and sprinkling and mistifying the gardens of the deep, as with so
many sprinkling or mistifying pots; and that for some centuries ğŸ”™,
thousands of hunters should have been ğŸ”š by the â›² of the
ğŸ³, watching these sprinklings and spoutings--that all this should
be, and yet, that down to this blessed minute (fifteen and a ğŸ’©
minutes past 1âƒ£ â­•'clock P.â“‚. of this sixteenth day of December, A.D.
1851), it should ğŸ˜¯ remain a problem, whether these spoutings
are, after all, really water, or 0âƒ£ but vapour--this is surely a
noteworthy thing.

Let us, then, look at this matter, ğŸ”› with some interesting items
contingent. Every 1âƒ£ knows that by the peculiar cunning of their
gills, the finny tribes in general breathe the air which at all times is
combined with the element in which they swim; hence, a herring or a cod
might live a ğŸ’¯, and never once ğŸ”¥ its â“ above the ğŸŒ¹.
But owing to his marked internal ğŸš§ which gives him regular
lungs, like a ğŸ‘¨ being's, the ğŸ³ can only live by inhaling the
disengaged air in the open ğŸ§. Wherefore the necessity for
his periodical visits to the upper ğŸ‘¨. But he cannot in any degree
breathe through his ğŸ‘„, for, in his ordinary attitude, the Sperm
ğŸ³'s ğŸ‘„ is buried at least 8âƒ£ feet beneath the ğŸŒ¹; and
what is ğŸ˜¯ more, his windpipe has no ğŸ”— with his ğŸ‘„. No, he
breathes through his spiracle alone; and this is on the ğŸ” of his â“.

If I say, that in any creature breathing is only a ğŸƒ
indispensable to vitality, inasmuch as it withdraws from the air a
certain element, which being subsequently brought into ğŸ”— with the
blood imparts to the blood its vivifying principle, I do not think I
shall err; though I may possibly use some superfluous scientific words.
ğŸ‰‘ it, and it follows that if all the blood in a ğŸ‘¨ could be
aerated with 1âƒ£ breath, he might then seal up his nostrils and not
fetch another for a considerable time. That is to say, he would then
live without breathing. Anomalous as it may seem, this is precisely the
ğŸš with the ğŸ³, who systematically lives, by intervals, his full
hour and more (when at the ğŸ’º) without drawing a 1âƒ£ breath, or
so much as in any way inhaling a particle of air; for, remember, he has
no gills. How is this? Between his ribs and on each side of his ğŸ”™
he is supplied with a remarkable involved Cretan labyrinth of
vermicelli-like vessels, which vessels, when he quits the ğŸŒ¹, are
completely distended with oxygenated blood. So that for an hour or more,
a â“‚ fathoms in the ğŸŒŠ, he carries a surplus stock of vitality in
him, just as the ğŸ« crossing the waterless desert carries a surplus
supply of drink for future use in its 4âƒ£ supplementary stomachs.
The anatomical fact of this labyrinth is indisputable; and that the
supposition founded upon it is reasonable and true, seems the more
cogent to me, when I consider the otherwise inexplicable obstinacy of
that leviathan in HAVING HIS SPOUTINGS OUT, as the fishermen phrase
it. This is what I mean. If unmolested, upon rising to the ğŸŒ¹, the
Sperm ğŸ³ will continue there for a period of time exactly uniform
with all his other unmolested risings. Say he stays eleven minutes, and
jets seventy times, that is, respires seventy breaths; then whenever he
rises again, he will be sure to have his seventy breaths over again, to
a minute. Now, if after he fetches a few breaths you alarm him, so that
he sounds, he will be always dodging up again to ğŸ’© ğŸ”‰ his regular
allowance of air. And not till those seventy breaths are told, will he
finally âŒ down to stay out his full term below. ğŸ¶, however, that
in different individuals these rates are different; but in any 1âƒ£
they are alike. Now, why should the ğŸ³ thus insist upon having his
spoutings out, unless it be to replenish his reservoir of air, ere
descending for ğŸ”‰? How obvious is it, too, that this necessity for the
ğŸ³'s rising exposes him to all the fatal hazards of the ğŸ¶. For
not by ğŸ‘® or by net could this vast leviathan be caught, when sailing
a â“‚ fathoms beneath the sunlight. Not so much thy skill, then, â­•
hunter, as the great necessities that strike the ğŸ˜¤ to thee!

In ğŸ‘¨, breathing is incessantly going on--1âƒ£ breath only serving
for 2âƒ£ or 3âƒ£ pulsations; so that whatever other business he has to
attend to, waking or ğŸ˜´, breathe he must, or die he will. But the
Sperm ğŸ³ only breathes about 1âƒ£ seventh or Sunday of his time.

It has been said that the ğŸ³ only breathes through his spout-hole; if
it could truthfully be added that his spouts are mixed with water, then
I opine we should be furnished with the reason why his sense of smell
seems obliterated in him; for the only thing about him that at all
answers to his ğŸ‘ƒ is that identical spout-hole; and being so clogged
with 2âƒ£ elements, it could not be expected to have the ğŸ¢ of
smelling. But owing to the ãŠ™ of the spout--whether it be water or
whether it be vapour--no absolute certainty can as yet be arrived at on
this â“. Sure it is, nevertheless, that the Sperm ğŸ³ has no proper
olfactories. But what does he want of them? No roses, no violets, no
Cologne-water in the ğŸŒŠ.

Furthermore, as his windpipe solely opens into the ğŸš‡ of his spouting
canal, and as that long canal--like the â“‚ Erie Canal--is furnished
with a sort of locks (that open and shut) for the downward retention of

unless you insult him by saying, that when he so strangely rumbles,
he talks through his ğŸ‘ƒ. But then again, what has the ğŸ³ to say?
Seldom have I known any ğŸ”‰ being that had anything to say to
this ğŸ‘¨, unless forced to stammer out something by way of getting a
living. Oh! happy that the ğŸ‘¨ is such an excellent listener!

Now, the spouting canal of the Sperm ğŸ³, chiefly intended as it
is for the conveyance of air, and for several feet laid ğŸ”›,
horizontally, just beneath the upper ğŸŒ¹ of his â“, and a little
to 1âƒ£ side; this curious canal is very much like a ğŸ”«-pipe laid down

ğŸ”«-pipe is also a water-pipe; in other words, whether the spout of the
Sperm ğŸ³ is the mere vapour of the exhaled breath, or whether that
exhaled breath is mixed with water taken in at the ğŸ‘„, and
discharged through the spiracle. It is certain that the ğŸ‘„ indirectly
communicates with the spouting canal; but it cannot be proved that this
is for the purpose of discharging water through the spiracle. Because
the greatest necessity for so doing would seem to be, when in feeding he
accidentally takes in water. But the Sperm ğŸ³'s food is far beneath
the ğŸŒ¹, and there he cannot spout ğŸ˜³ if he would. Besides, if
you regard him very closely, and time him with your âŒš, you will find
that when unmolested, there is an undeviating rhyme between the periods
of his jets and the ordinary periods of respiration.

But why ğŸ› 1âƒ£ with all this reasoning on the subject? Speak out!
You have seen him spout; then declare what the spout is; can you not
tell water from air? My dear sir, in this ğŸ‘¨ it is not so easy to
settle these plain things. I have ever found your plain things the
knottiest of all. And as for this ğŸ³ spout, you might almost ğŸ» in
it, and yet be undecided as to what it is precisely.

The ğŸ”‘ body of it is ãŠ™ in the snowy sparkling â˜ enveloping
it; and how can you certainly tell whether any water falls from it,
when, always, when you are ğŸ”š enough to a ğŸ³ to get a ğŸ”š âŒš
of his spout, he is in a prodigious commotion, the water cascading
all around him. And if at such times you should think that you really
perceived drops of moisture in the spout, how do you know that they are
not merely condensed from its vapour; or how do you know that they
are not those identical drops superficially lodged in the spout-hole
fissure, which is countersunk into the ğŸ” of the ğŸ³'s â“? For
ğŸ˜³ when tranquilly swimming through the mid-day ğŸŒŠ in a calm, with

In all directions expanding in vast irregular circles, and aimlessly

thousands, the lion-maned buffaloes of the West have fled before a
solitary horseman. Witness, too, all ğŸ‘¨ beings, how when herded

infinitely outdone by the ğŸ˜¡ of ğŸš¹.

Though many of the whales, as has been said, were in violent â“,

All whaleboats ğŸƒ certain curious contrivances, originally invented

CHAPTER 88. Schools and Schoolmasters.


The previous chapter gave account of an immense body or herd of Sperm
Whales, and there was also then given the probable cause inducing those
vast aggregations.

Now, though such great bodies are at times encountered, yet, as must
have been seen, ğŸ˜³ at the ğŸ day, small ğŸ†“ bands are
occasionally observed, embracing from twenty to fifty individuals each.
Such bands are known as schools. They generally are of 2âƒ£ sorts; those
composed almost entirely of females, and those mustering none but ğŸ†•
vigorous males, or bulls, as they are familiarly designated.

In cavalier attendance upon the ğŸ« of females, you invariably ğŸ“… a
male of full grown magnitude, but not old; who, upon any alarm, evinces
his gallantry by falling in the ğŸŒ¹ and covering the flight of his
ladies. In truth, this ğŸ‘¨ is a luxurious Ottoman, swimming about
over the watery ğŸ‘¨, surroundingly accompanied by all the solaces
and endearments of the harem. The contrast between this Ottoman and
his concubines is striking; because, while he is always of the largest
leviathanic proportions, the ladies, ğŸ˜³ at full growth, are not
more than 1âƒ£-third of the bulk of an average-sized male. They are
comparatively delicate, indeed; I dare say, not to ğŸ” half a dozen
yards round the waist. Nevertheless, it cannot be denied, that upon the
whole they are hereditarily entitled to EMBONPOINT.

It is very curious to âŒš this harem and its lord in their indolent
ramblings. Like fashionables, they are for ever on the ğŸƒ in leisurely
search of variety. You ğŸ˜† them on the ğŸ¶ in time for the full ğŸŒ¼
of the Equatorial feeding season, having just returned, perhaps, from
spending the summer in the Northern seas, and so cheating summer of all
unpleasant weariness and warmth. By the time they have lounged up and
down the promenade of the Equator awhile, they start for the Oriental
waters in anticipation of the ğŸ†’ season there, and so evade the other
excessive temperature of the year.

When serenely advancing on 1âƒ£ of these journeys, if any strange
suspicious sights are seen, my lord ğŸ³ keeps a wary â™¥ on his
interesting ğŸ . Should any unwarrantably pert ğŸ†• Leviathan coming
that way, presume to ğŸƒ confidentially ğŸ”š to 1âƒ£ of the ladies,
with what prodigious ğŸ˜¡ the Bashaw assails him, and chases him away!
High times, indeed, if unprincipled ğŸ†• rakes like him are to be
permitted to invade the sanctity of domestic bliss; though do what the
Bashaw will, he cannot keep the most notorious Lothario out of his bed;
for, alas! all ğŸŸ bed in common. As ashore, the ladies often cause the
most ğŸ˜¨ duels among their rival admirers; just so with the whales,
who sometimes come to deadly battle, and all for love. They fence with
their long ğŸ˜¦ jaws, sometimes locking them together, and so striving
for the supremacy like elks that warringly interweave their antlers. Not
a few are captured having the deep scars of these encounters,--furrowed
heads, ğŸ˜• teeth, scolloped fins; and in some instances, wrenched and
dislocated mouths.

But supposing the invader of domestic bliss to betake himself away at
the first ğŸ‘¢ of the harem's lord, then is it very diverting to âŒš
that lord. Gently he insinuates his vast bulk among them again and

like pious Solomon devoutly worshipping among his â“‚ concubines.
Granting other whales to be in sight, the fishermen will seldom ğŸƒ
ğŸ¶ to 1âƒ£ of these â“‚ Turks; for these â“‚ Turks are too ğŸš¿
of their strength, and hence their unctuousness is small. As for the

Now, as the harem of whales is called by the fishermen a ğŸ«, so
is the lord and master of that ğŸ« technically known as the

The same secludedness and isolation to which the schoolmaster ğŸ³
betakes himself in his advancing years, is true of all aged Sperm

called--proves an ancient 1âƒ£. Like venerable moss-bearded Daniel Boone,
he will have no 1âƒ£ near him but Nature herself; and her he takes to

she keeps so many moody secrets.

The schools composing none but ğŸ†• and vigorous males, previously

excepting those wondrous grey-headed, grizzled whales, sometimes met,
and these will fight you like grim fiends exasperated by a penal gout.

The Forty-barrel-ğŸ· schools are larger than the harem schools. Like
a ğŸ’ of ğŸ†• collegians, they are full of fight, fun, and wickedness,
tumbling round the ğŸ‘¨ at such a reckless, rollicking rate, that no

and when about 3âƒ£-fourths grown, break up, and separately âŒ about in

Another point of difference between the male and female schools is
ğŸ˜¯ more characteristic of the sexes. Say you strike a

a member of the harem ğŸ«, and her companions swim around her with
every token of ğŸ˜Ÿ, sometimes lingering so near her and so long, as
themselves to fall a prey.



CHAPTER 89. Fast-ğŸŸ and ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ.


The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the ğŸ”š chapter but 1âƒ£,
necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the ğŸ³
fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the â“‚ ğŸ”£ and badge.

It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in company,
a ğŸ³ may be struck by 1âƒ£ vessel, then ğŸƒ, and be finally killed
and captured by another vessel; and herein are indirectly comprised
many ğŸ” contingencies, all partaking of this 1âƒ£ â“‚ feature. For
example,--after a ğŸ˜© and perilous ğŸ¶ and capture of a ğŸ³,
the body may get ğŸ†“ from the ğŸš¢ by reason of a violent ğŸ˜¡; and
drifting far away to leeward, be retaken by a ğŸ”™ whaler, who, in a
calm, snugly tows it alongside, without risk of life or ğŸ¶. Thus
the most vexatious and violent disputes would often ğŸŒ¹ between
the fishermen, were there not some written or unwritten, universal,
undisputed law applicable to all cases.

Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative
enactment, was that of Holland. It was decreed by the States-General in
A.D. 1695. But though no other nation has ever had any written whaling
law, yet the American fishermen have been their own legislators and
lawyers in this matter. They have provided a system which for terse
comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian's Pandects and the By-laws of
the Chinese â™£ for the Suppression of Meddling with other People's
Business. Yes; these laws might be engraven on a Queen Anne's farthing,
or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the neck, so small are they.

I. A Fast-ğŸŸ belongs to the party fast to it.

2âƒ£. A ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ is fair ğŸ”™ for anybody who can soonest âŒš it.

But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable
brevity of it, which necessitates a vast ğŸ“– of commentaries to
expound it.

First: What is a Fast-ğŸŸ? Alive or dead a ğŸŸ is technically fast,
when it is connected with an occupied ğŸš¢ or â›µ, by any medium at all
controllable by the occupant or occupants,--a mast, an oar, a â™£-inch
cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it is all the same.
Likewise a ğŸŸ is technically fast when it bears a waif, or any other
recognised ğŸ”£ of possession; so long as the party waifing it plainly
evince their ability at any time to ğŸ‰‘ it alongside, as well as their
intention so to do.

These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the whalemen
themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder knocks--the
Coke-upon-Littleton of the âœŠ. True, among the more upright and
honourable whalemen allowances are always made for peculiar cases,
where it would be an outrageous moral injustice for 1âƒ£ party to claim
possession of a ğŸ³ previously chased or killed by another party. But
others are by no means so scrupulous.

Some fifty years ago there was a curious ğŸš of ğŸ³-trover litigated
in England, wherein the plaintiffs ğŸ‘— forth that after a hard ğŸ¶ of
a ğŸ³ in the Northern seas; and when indeed they (the plaintiffs) had
succeeded in harpooning the ğŸŸ; they were at ğŸ”š, through peril of
their lives, obliged to forsake not only their lines, but their â›µ
itself. Ultimately the defendants (the crew of another ğŸš¢) came up
with the ğŸ³, struck, killed, seized, and finally appropriated it
before the very eyes of the plaintiffs. And when those defendants were
remonstrated with, their captain snapped his fingers in the plaintiffs'
teeth, and assured them that by way of doxology to the deed he had done,
he would now retain their ğŸ¶, harpoons, and â›µ, which had remained
attached to the ğŸ³ at the time of the seizure. Wherefore the
plaintiffs now sued for the recovery of the value of their ğŸ³, ğŸ¶,
harpoons, and â›µ.

Mr. Erskine was counsel for the defendants; Lord Ellenborough was
the judge. In the ğŸƒ of the defence, the witty Erskine went on
to illustrate his ğŸ¢, by alluding to a recent crim. con.
ğŸš, wherein a ğŸ‘¨, after in vain trying to bridle his wife's
viciousness, had at ğŸ”š abandoned her upon the seas of life; but in
the ğŸƒ of years, repenting of that ğŸ‘£, he instituted an action to
recover possession of her. Erskine was on the other side; and he
then supported it by saying, that though the ğŸ‘¨ had originally
harpooned the lady, and had once had her fast, and only by reason of the
great stress of her plunging viciousness, had at ğŸ”š abandoned her; yet
abandon her he did, so that she became a ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ; and therefore
when a subsequent ğŸ‘¨ re-harpooned her, the lady then became that
subsequent ğŸ‘¨'s property, ğŸ”› with whatever harpoon might have
been found ğŸ˜Œ in her.

Now in the ğŸ ğŸš Erskine contended that the examples of the ğŸ³
and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other.

These pleadings, and the counter pleadings, being duly heard, the very
learned Judge in ğŸ‘— terms decided, to wit,--That as for the â›µ, he
awarded it to the plaintiffs, because they had merely abandoned it
to ğŸ˜Œ their lives; but that with regard to the controverted ğŸ³,
harpoons, and ğŸ¶, they belonged to the defendants; the ğŸ³, because
it was a ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ at the time of the final capture; and the harpoons
and ğŸ¶ because when the ğŸŸ made off with them, it (the ğŸŸ)
acquired a property in those articles; and hence anybody who afterwards
took the ğŸŸ had a right to them. Now the defendants afterwards took
the ğŸŸ; ergo, the aforesaid articles were theirs.

A common ğŸ‘¨ looking at this decision of the very learned Judge, might
possibly object to it. But ploughed up to the primary rock of the
matter, the 2âƒ£ great principles laid down in the ğŸ‘« whaling laws
previously quoted, and applied and elucidated by Lord Ellenborough in
the above cited ğŸš; these 2âƒ£ laws touching Fast-ğŸŸ and ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ,
I say, will, on reflection, be found the fundamentals of all ğŸ‘¨
jurisprudence; for notwithstanding its complicated tracery of sculpture,
the Temple of the Law, like the Temple of the Philistines, has but 2âƒ£
props to ğŸ» on.

Is it not a saying in every 1âƒ£'s ğŸ‘„, Possession is half of the law:
that is, regardless of how the thing came into possession? But often
possession is the whole of the law. What are the sinews and souls of
Russian serfs and Republican slaves but Fast-ğŸŸ, whereof possession is
the whole of the law? What to the rapacious landlord is the widow's ğŸ”š
mite but a Fast-ğŸŸ? What is yonder undetected villain's marble ğŸ 
with a ğŸšª-ğŸš for a waif; what is that but a Fast-ğŸŸ? What is the
ruinous discount which Mordecai, the broker, gets from poor Woebegone,
the bankrupt, on a loan to keep Woebegone's ğŸ  from starvation;
what is that ruinous discount but a Fast-ğŸŸ? What is the Archbishop of
Savesoul's income of L100,000 seized from the scant ğŸ and cheese
of hundreds of thousands of ğŸ˜•-backed laborers (all sure of heaven
without any of Savesoul's help) what is that globular L100,000 but a
Fast-ğŸŸ? What are the Duke of Dunder's hereditary towns and hamlets
but Fast-ğŸŸ? What to that redoubted harpooneer, ğŸš½ ğŸ·, is poor
Ireland, but a Fast-ğŸŸ? What to that apostolic lancer, Brother
Jonathan, is Texas but a Fast-ğŸŸ? And concerning all these, is not
Possession the whole of the law?

But if the doctrine of Fast-ğŸŸ be pretty generally applicable,
the kindred doctrine of ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ is ğŸ˜¯ more widely so. That is
internationally and universally applicable.

What was America in 1492 but a ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ, in which Columbus struck the
Spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and mistress?
What was Poland to the Czar? What Greece to the Turk? What India
to England? What at ğŸ”š will Mexico be to the United States? All
ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ.

What are the Rights of ğŸ‘¨ and the Liberties of the ğŸ‘¨ but
ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ? What all ğŸš¹'s minds and opinions but ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ? What is
the principle of religious belief in them but a ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ? What to
the ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thoughts of thinkers but

are you, reader, but a ğŸ†“-ğŸŸ and a Fast-ğŸŸ, too?



CHAPTER 90. Heads or Tails.


"De balena vero sufficit, si rex habeat caput, et regina caudam."
BRACTON, L. 3âƒ£, ğŸ’¯. 3âƒ£.


Latin from the books of the Laws of England, which taken ğŸ”› with the
context, means, that of all whales captured by anybody on the coast of
that land, the King, as Honourary â“‚ Harpooneer, must have the â“,
and the Queen be respectfully presented with the ğŸ’©. A division which,

It seems that some honest mariners of Dover, or Sandwich, or some 1âƒ£

Holding the ğŸ¢ directly from the ğŸ”, I believe, all the royal
emoluments incident to the 5âƒ£ Port territories become by assignment

Because the Lord Warden is busily employed at times in fobbing his
perquisites; which are his chiefly by virtue of that same fobbing of
them.

Now when these poor sun-burnt mariners, bare-footed, and with their

he says--"Hands off! this ğŸŸ, my masters, is a Fast-ğŸŸ. I seize it

"Please, sir, who is the Lord Warden?"

"The Duke."

"But the duke had 0âƒ£ to do with taking this ğŸŸ?"

"It is his."

"We have been at great trouble, and peril, and some expense, and is

pains but our blisters?"

"It is his."

"Is the Duke so very poor as to be forced to this desperate mode of

"It is his."

"I thought to ğŸ†“ my old bed-ridden mother by ğŸ¢ of my share of
this ğŸ³."

"It is his."

"Won't the Duke be content with a ğŸ’© or a half?"

"It is his."

In a word, the ğŸ³ was seized and sold, and his Grace the Duke of
Wellington received the money. Thinking that viewed in some particular

It will readily be seen that in this ğŸš the alleged right of the

inquire then on what principle the Sovereign is originally invested with

the King and Queen, "because of its superior excellence." And by the
soundest commentators this has ever been held a cogent argument in such
matters.

But why should the King have the â“, and the Queen the ğŸ’©? A reason
for that, ye lawyers!

In his treatise on "Queen-Gold," or Queen-pinmoney, an old King's Bench
author, 1âƒ£ William Prynne, thus discourseth: "Ye ğŸ’© is ye Queen's,
that ye Queen's wardrobe may be supplied with ye whalebone." Now this

is not in the ğŸ’©; it is in the â“, which is a sad mistake for
a sagacious lawyer like Prynne. But is the Queen a mermaid, to be
presented with a ğŸ’©? An allegorical meaning may lurk here.

There are 2âƒ£ royal ğŸŸ so styled by the English law writers--the ğŸ³
and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain limitations, and
nominally supplying the tenth branch of the ğŸ”'s ordinary revenue.
I know not that any other author has hinted of the matter; but by
inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be divided in the same
way as the ğŸ³, the King receiving the highly dense and elastic â“
peculiar to that ğŸŸ, which, symbolically regarded, may possibly be
humorously grounded upon some presumed congeniality. And thus there
seems a reason in all things, ğŸ˜³ in law.

"Why, let me ğŸ“…; yes, you may as well tell him now that--that--in

"He says, Monsieur, that he's very happy to have been of any service to

CHAPTER 92. Ambergris.


Now this ambergris is a very curious â™¥, and so important as
an article of commerce, that in 1791 a certain Nantucket-born Captain
Coffin was examined at the ğŸ° of the English ğŸ  of Commons on that
subject. For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively late day,
the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber itself, a problem
to the learned. Though the word ambergris is but the French compound for
grey amber, yet the 2âƒ£ substances are quite distinct. For amber, though
at times found on the ğŸŒŠ-coast, is also dug up in some far inland
soils, whereas ambergris is never found except upon the ğŸŒŠ. Besides,
amber is a hard, transparent, brittle, odorless â™¥, used for
ğŸ‘„-pieces to pipes, for beads and ornaments; but ambergris is soft,
waxy, and so highly fragrant and spicy, that it is largely used in
perfumery, in pastiles, precious candles, hair-powders, and pomatum.
The Turks use it in cooking, and also ğŸƒ it to Mecca, for the same
purpose that frankincense is carried to St. Peter's in Rome. Some wine
merchants drop a few grains into claret, to flavor it.

Who would think, then, that such ğŸ†— ladies and gentlemen should regale
themselves with an â™¥ found in the inglorious bowels of a ğŸ±
ğŸ³! Yet so it is. By some, ambergris is supposed to be the cause, and
by others the effect, of the dyspepsia in the ğŸ³. How to cure such
a dyspepsia it were hard to say, unless by administering 3âƒ£ or 4âƒ£

laborers do in blasting rocks.

I have forgotten to say that there were found in this ambergris, certain
hard, round, bony plates, which at first Stubb thought might be sailors'
trowsers buttons; but it afterwards turned out that they were 0âƒ£
more than pieces of small squid bones embalmed in that manner.

Now that the incorruption of this most fragrant ambergris should be
found in the â™¥ of such decay; is this 0âƒ£? Bethink thee of that
saying of St. Paul in Corinthians, about corruption and incorruption;
how that we are sown in dishonour, but raised in glory. And likewise

the best musk. Also ğŸƒ not the strange fact that of all things of
ill-savor, Cologne-water, in its rudimental manufacturing stages, is the
worst.

I should like to conclude the chapter with the above appeal, but cannot,
owing to my anxiety to repel a ğŸ‘¢ often made against whalemen,
and which, in the estimation of some already biased minds, might be
considered as indirectly substantiated by what has been said of
the Frenchman's 2âƒ£ whales. Elsewhere in this ğŸ“– the slanderous
aspersion has been disproved, that the ğŸ“² of whaling is throughout
a slatternly, untidy business. But there is another thing to rebut. They
hint that all whales always smell bad. Now how did this odious stigma
ğŸŒ¹?

I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the
Greenland whaling ships in London, more than 2âƒ£ centuries ago. Because
those whalemen did not then, and do not now, try out their oil at ğŸŒŠ as
the Southern ships have always done; but cutting up the ğŸ†• blubber in
small bits, thrust it through the bung holes of large casks, and ğŸƒ
it ğŸ  in that manner; the shortness of the season in those Icy Seas,
and the sudden and violent storms to which they are exposed, forbidding
any other ğŸƒ. The consequence is, that upon breaking into the ğŸ“–,
and unloading 1âƒ£ of these ğŸ³ cemeteries, in the Greenland dock, a
savor is given forth somewhat similar to that arising from excavating an
old city grave-â“‚, for the foundations of a Lying-in-ğŸ¥.

I partly surmise also, that this wicked ğŸ‘¢ against whalers may be

latter ğŸ”‘ is the 1âƒ£ used by the learned Fogo Von â˜º, in his great
ğŸƒ on Smells, a text-ğŸ“– on that subject. As its ğŸ”‘ imports (smeer,

years perhaps, after completely filling her ğŸ“– with oil, does not,

living or dead, if but decently treated, whales as a species are by

people of the â™¥ ages affected to detect a Jew in the company, by
the ğŸ‘ƒ. Nor indeed can the ğŸ³ possibly be otherwise than fragrant,
when, as a general thing, he enjoys such high health; taking abundance

But had Stubb really abandoned the poor little negro to his fate? No; he

But it so happened, that those boats, without seeing Pip, suddenly

For the rest, blame not Stubb too hardly. The thing is common in that

CHAPTER 94. A Squeeze of the ğŸš¹.


That ğŸ³ of Stubb's, so dearly purchased, was duly brought to
the Pequod's side, where all those cutting and hoisting operations

the Heidelburgh Tun, or ğŸš.

While some were occupied with this latter duty, others were employed

when the proper time arrived, this same sperm was carefully manipulated
ere going to the try-works, of which anon.

It had cooled and crystallized to such a degree, that when, with several
others, I sat down before a large Constantine's ğŸ›€ of it, I found
it strangely concreted into lumps, here and there rolling about in the
liquid ğŸ¢. It was our business to squeeze these lumps ğŸ”™ into fluid.
A sweet and unctuous duty! No â“ that in old times this sperm was
such a favourite cosmetic. Such a clearer! such a sweetener! such a
softener! such a delicious molifier! After having my hands in it for
only a few minutes, my fingers felt like eels, and began, as it were, to
serpentine and spiralise.

As I sat there at my ğŸ˜Œ, cross-legged on the deck; after the bitter
ğŸ˜“ at the windlass; under a blue tranquil sky; the ğŸš¢ under
indolent sail, and gliding so serenely ğŸ”›; as I bathed my hands among
those soft, gentle globules of infiltrated tissues, woven almost within

uncontaminated aroma,--literally and truly, like the smell of â›²
violets; I declare to you, that for the time I lived as in a musky
meadow; I forgot all about our horrible oath; in that inexpressible
sperm, I washed my hands and my â™¥ of it; I almost began to credit
the old Paracelsan superstition that sperm is of rare virtue in allaying
the heat of ğŸ’¢; while bathing in that ğŸ›€, I felt divinely ğŸ˜‡ from
all ill-will, or petulance, or malice, of any sort whatsoever.

Squeeze! squeeze! squeeze! all the ğŸŒ… long; I squeezed that sperm
till I myself almost melted into it; I squeezed that sperm till a
strange sort of insanity came over me; and I found myself unwittingly
squeezing my co-laborers' hands in it, mistaking their hands for the
gentle globules. Such an abounding, affectionate, friendly, loving
feeling did this avocation beget; that at ğŸ”š I was continually
squeezing their hands, and looking up into their eyes sentimentally; as
much as to say,--Oh! my dear fellow beings, why should we longer cherish
any social acerbities, or know the slightest ill-humor or envy! Come;
let us squeeze hands all round; nay, let us all squeeze ourselves into
each other; let us squeeze ourselves universally into the very milk and
sperm of kindness.

Would that I could keep squeezing that sperm for ever! For now, since by
many prolonged, repeated experiences, I have perceived that in all cases
ğŸ‘¨ must eventually ğŸ˜¦, or at least shift, his conceit of attainable
felicity; not placing it anywhere in the intellect or the fancy; but in
the wife, the â™¥, the bed, the table, the saddle, the fireside, the
country; now that I have perceived all this, I am ready to squeeze ğŸš
eternally. In thoughts of the visions of the night, I saw long rows of
angels in paradise, each with his hands in a jar of spermaceti.

Now, while discoursing of sperm, it behooves to speak of other things
akin to it, in the business of preparing the sperm ğŸ³ for the
try-works.

First comes white-ğŸ´, so called, which is obtained from the tapering
ğŸ¢ of the ğŸŸ, and also from the thicker portions of his flukes. It
is tough with congealed tendons--a ğŸ of ğŸ’ª--but ğŸ˜¯ contains
some oil. After being severed from the ğŸ³, the white-ğŸ´ is first

blocks of Berkshire marble.

Plum-pudding is the term bestowed upon certain fragmentary parts of the
ğŸ³'s flesh, here and there adhering to the blanket of blubber, and
often participating to a considerable degree in its unctuousness. It is

There is another â™¥, and a very singular 1âƒ£, which turns up in
the ğŸƒ of this business, but which I feel it to be very puzzling

It is an ineffably oozy, stringy affair, most frequently found in the

I ğŸ“– it to be the wondrously thin, ruptured membranes of the ğŸš,
coalescing.

Gurry, so called, is a term properly belonging to right whalemen, but
sometimes incidentally used by the sperm fishermen. It designates the

or right ğŸ³, and much of which covers the decks of those inferior

Nippers. Strictly this word is not indigenous to the ğŸ³'s vocabulary.
But as applied by whalemen, it becomes so. A whaleman's ğŸŸ is
a short ğŸ  strip of tendinous stuff cut from the tapering ğŸ¢ of

But to âŒš all about these recondite matters, your best way is at once
to descend into the blubber-room, and have a long ğŸ‘ with its inmates.
This ğŸš‰ has previously been mentioned as the receptacle for the

ğŸ®, a space has been left ğŸ” for the workmen. They generally

similar to a frigate's boarding-weapon of the same ğŸ”‘. The gaff is
something like a â›µ-ğŸ‘®. With his gaff, the gaffman hooks on to a

pitches and lurches about. Meanwhile, the â™ -ğŸ‘¨ stands on the sheet

the thing he stands on will sometimes irresistibly slide away from

assistants', would you be very much ğŸ˜²? Toes are scarce among

CHAPTER 95. The Cassock.


Had you stepped on board the Pequod at a certain juncture of this

Look at the sailor, called the mincer, who now comes ğŸ”›, and assisted

That ğŸ¢ consists in mincing the ğŸ´-pieces of blubber for the

Pope were this mincer!*


*Bible leaves! Bible leaves! This is the invariable ğŸ˜¢ from the mates
to the mincer. It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his ğŸƒ into as
thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business of
boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity considerably
increased, besides perhaps ğŸ†™ it in quality.



CHAPTER 96. The Try-Works.


Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly distinguished
by her try-works. She presents the curious anomaly of the most solid
masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the completed ğŸš¢.
It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were transported to her
planks.

The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the most
roomy ğŸ¢ of the deck. The timbers beneath are of a peculiar strength,
fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of brick and
mortar, some âŒ feet by 8âƒ£ square, and 5âƒ£ in ğŸ”. The
ğŸ¾ does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly

sides, and screwing it down to the timbers. On the flanks it is cased

kept remarkably clean. Sometimes they are polished with soapstone
and sand, till they shine within like silver ğŸ‘Š-bowls. During the
night-watches some cynical old sailors will crawl into them and ğŸ“œ
themselves away there for a nap. While employed in polishing them--1âƒ£
ğŸ‘¨ in each ğŸš½, side by side--many ãŠ™ communications
are carried on, over the iron lips. It is a ğŸš‰ also for ğŸ”‰
mathematical meditation. It was in the left ğŸš¹ try-ğŸš½ of the Pequod,
with the soapstone diligently circling round me, that I was first

gliding ğŸ”› the cycloid, my soapstone for example, will descend from
any point in precisely the same time.

Removing the ğŸ”¥-board from the front of the try-works, the bare

from the ğŸŒ¹ wall. And here let us âŒ ğŸ”™ for a moment.

It was about â™£ â­•'clock at night that the Pequod's try-works were
first started on this ğŸ voyage. It belonged to Stubb to oversee

"All ready there? Off hatch, then, and start her. You cook, ğŸ”¥ the
works." This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been thrusting his

in a whaling voyage the first ğŸ”¥ in the try-works has to be fed for a
time with wood. After that no wood is used, except as a means of quick
ignition to the staple ğŸ”¥. In a word, after being tried out, the
crisp, shrivelled blubber, now called scraps or fritters, ğŸ˜¯ contains
considerable of its unctuous properties. These fritters ğŸƒ the flames.
Like a plethoric burning martyr, or a self-consuming misanthrope, once
ignited, the ğŸ³ supplies his own ğŸ”¥ and burns by his own body.
Would that he consumed his own ğŸš¬! for his ğŸš¬ is horrible to
inhale, and inhale it you must, and not only that, but you must live in
it for the time. It has an unspeakable, ğŸ˜ , Hindoo odor about it, such
as may lurk in the vicinity of funereal pyres. It smells like the left
wing of the day of judgment; it is an argument for the pit.

By midnight the works were in full operation. We were ğŸ” from the
carcase; sail had been made; the ğŸ‘ƒ was freshening; the ğŸ˜  ğŸŒŠ

The hatch, removed from the ğŸ” of the works, now afforded a wide hearth

So seemed it to me, as I stood at her helm, and for long hours silently

But that night, in particular, a strange (and ever since inexplicable)

Look not too long in the face of the ğŸ”¥, â­• ğŸ‘¨! Never dream with thy

Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia's Dismal Swamp, nor Rome's

which is the dark side of this earth, and which is 2âƒ£ thirds of this

But ğŸ˜³ Solomon, he says, "the ğŸ‘¨ that wandereth out of the way

CHAPTER 97. The Lamp.


Had you descended from the Pequod's try-works to the Pequod's

score of lamps flashing upon his hooded eyes.

In merchantmen, oil for the sailor is more scarce than the milk of
queens. To ğŸ› in the dark, and eat in the dark, and stumble in
darkness to his pallet, this is his usual lot. But the whaleman, as he

the ğŸš¢'s black hull ğŸ˜¯ houses an illumination.

ğŸ“… with what entire freedom the whaleman takes his handful of
lamps--often but old bottles and vials, though--to the ğŸ· cooler at
the try-works, and replenishes them there, as mugs of ale at a vat. He
burns, too, the purest of oil, in its unmanufactured, and, therefore,
unvitiated state; a fluid ğŸ‘½ to solar, lunar, or astral
contrivances ashore. It is sweet as early ğŸ€ butter in April. He
goes and hunts for his oil, so as to be sure of its freshness and
genuineness, ğŸ˜³ as the traveller on the prairie hunts up his own
supper of ğŸ”™.



CHAPTER 98. Stowing Down and Clearing Up.


Already has it been related how the great leviathan is afar off

slaughtered in the valleys of the deep; how he is then towed alongside
and beheaded; and how (on the principle which entitled the headsman of
old to the garments in which the beheaded was killed) his great padded
surtout becomes the property of his executioner; how, in due time, he
is condemned to the pots, and, like Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, his
spermaceti, oil, and bone pass unscathed through the ğŸ”¥;--but now it
remains to conclude the ğŸ”š chapter of this ğŸ¢ of the description by

once again leviathan returns to his native profundities, sliding ğŸ”›
beneath the ğŸŒ¹ as before; but, alas! never more to ğŸŒ¹ and blow.

While ğŸ˜¯ warm, the oil, like hot ğŸ‘Š, is received into the

every sailor is a cooper.

At length, when the ğŸ”š pint is casked, and all is ğŸ†’, then the great

In the sperm fishery, this is perhaps 1âƒ£ of the most remarkable

But a day or 2âƒ£ after, you look about you, and ğŸ˜­ your ears in this

most scrupulously neat commander. The unmanufactured sperm oil possesses
a singularly cleansing virtue. This is the reason why the decks never
look so white as just after what they â˜ an affair of oil. Besides,
from the ashes of the burned scraps of the ğŸ³, a potent lye is

But ğŸ¶: aloft there, at the 3âƒ£ mast heads, ğŸ» 3âƒ£ ğŸš¹ intent

Oh! the metempsychosis! Oh! Pythagoras, that in bright Greece, 2âƒ£

CHAPTER 99. The Doubloon.


Ere now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his ğŸ’©-deck,
taking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and mainmast; but

he was wont to pause in ğŸ”§ at each ğŸ¢, and ğŸ» there strangely

that glance shot like a javelin with the pointed intensity of his

then, as the same riveted glance fastened upon the riveted gold coin
there, he ğŸ˜¯ wore the same aspect of nailed firmness, only dashed

But 1âƒ£ ğŸŒ…, turning to pass the doubloon, he seemed to be ğŸ†•
attracted by the strange figures and inscriptions stamped on it, as

the cartload, as they do hills about Boston, to ğŸ˜† up some morass in

Now this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere out of the
â™¥ of gorgeous hills, whence, ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸ and west, over golden sands, the

ğŸ³'s talisman. Sometimes they talked it over in the ğŸ˜© âŒš by

live to spend it.

Now those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the sun
and tropic token-pieces. Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes; sun's disks
and stars; ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners ğŸ‘‹, are in
luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold seems almost to
derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories, by passing through
those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic.

It so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy example
of these things. On its round ğŸ’ it bore the letters, REPUBLICA DEL
ECUADOR: QUITO. So this bright coin came from a country planted in the
â™¥ of the ğŸ‘¨, and beneath the great equator, and named after it;
and it had been ğŸ± midway up the Andes, in the unwaning clime that
knows no autumn. Zoned by those letters you saw the likeness of 3âƒ£
Andes' summits; from 1âƒ£ a ğŸ”¥; a tower on another; on the third a
crowing ğŸ“; while arching over all was a segment of the partitioned
zodiac, the signs all marked with their usual cabalistics, and the

Before this equatorial coin, Ahab, not unobserved by others, was now
pausing.

"There's something ever egotistical in mountain-tops and towers, and
all other â“‚ and lofty things; look here,--3âƒ£ peaks as proud as

which, like a magician's ğŸ‘“, to each and every ğŸ‘¨ in ğŸ”§ but
mirrors ğŸ”™ his own ãŠ™ self. Great pains, small gains for those
who ask the ğŸ‘¨ to solve them; it cannot solve itself. Methinks now
this coined sun wears a ruddy face; but ğŸ“…! aye, he enters the ğŸ 
of storms, the equinox! and but 6âƒ£ months before he wheeled out of a
former equinox at Aries! From ğŸ˜¡ to ğŸ˜¡! So be it, then. Born in
throes, 't is fit that ğŸ‘¨ should live in pains and die in pangs! So be

Belshazzar's ğŸ˜¨ writing. I have never marked the coin inspectingly.

lest Truth shake me falsely."

It was a wondrous sight. The wood was green as mosses of the Icy

CHAPTER 103. Measurement of The ğŸ³'s Skeleton.


In the first ğŸš‰, I wish to lay before you a particular, plain

According to a careful calculation I have made, and which I partly ğŸ¾
upon Captain Scoresby's estimate, of seventy tons for the largest

But the ğŸ”™. For that, the best way we can consider it is, with a

CHAPTER 104. The Fossil ğŸ³.


From his mighty bulk the ğŸ³ affords a most congenial theme whereon

ğŸƒ. Not to tell over again his furlongs from spiracle to ğŸ’©,

Since I have undertaken to manhandle this Leviathan, it behooves me

1âƒ£ often hears of writers that ğŸŒ¹ and swell with their subject,

Ere entering upon the subject of Fossil Whales, I ğŸ my credentials
as a geologist, by stating that in my miscellaneous time I have been

wine-vaults, cellars, and cisterns of all sorts. Likewise, by way of
preliminary, I desire to remind the reader, that while in the earlier
geological strata there are found the fossils of monsters now almost
completely extinct; the subsequent relics discovered in what are called
the Tertiary formations seem the connecting, or at any rate intercepted
links, between the antichronical creatures, and those whose remote
posterity are said to have entered the Ark; all the Fossil Whales
hitherto discovered belong to the Tertiary period, which is the ğŸ”š
preceding the superficial formations. And though none of them
precisely answer to any known species of the ğŸ time, they are yet

ğŸ†“ ğŸ˜• fossils of pre-adamite whales, fragments of their bones
and skeletons, have within thirty years past, at various intervals, been

Among the more curious of such remains is ğŸ¢ of a ğŸ’€, which in the

But by far the most wonderful of all Cetacean relics was the almost

When I ğŸ» among these mighty Leviathan skeletons, skulls, tusks,

But not alone has this Leviathan left his pre-adamite traces in the

"Not far from the ğŸŒŠ-side, they have a Temple, the Rafters and Beams

CHAPTER 105. Does the ğŸ³'s Magnitude Diminish?--Will He Perish?


Inasmuch, then, as this Leviathan comes floundering down upon us from
