original bulk of his sires.

But upon investigation we find, that not only are the whales of the
ğŸ day superior in magnitude to those whose fossil remains are

belonging to its latter formations ğŸ” in size those of its earlier

Of all the pre-adamite whales yet exhumed, by far the largest is the
Alabama 1âƒ£ mentioned in the ğŸ”š chapter, and that was less than
seventy feet in length in the skeleton. Whereas, we have already seen,
that the tape-measure gives seventy-2âƒ£ feet for the skeleton of a large
sized modern ğŸ³. And I have heard, on whalemen's ğŸ¢, that
Sperm Whales have been captured near a ğŸ’¯ feet long at the time of
capture.

But may it not be, that while the whales of the ğŸ hour are an

it not be, that since Adam's time they have degenerated?

Assuredly, we must conclude so, if we are to credit the accounts of such
gentlemen as Pliny, and the ancient naturalists generally. For Pliny
tells us of Whales that embraced acres of living bulk, and Aldrovandus
of others which measured 8âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ feet in length--Rope Walks and
Thames Tunnels of Whales! And ğŸ˜³ in the days of Banks and Solander,

at 1âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ and twenty yards; that is, 3âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ and sixty feet.
And Lacepede, the French naturalist, in his elaborate history of whales,
in the very beginning of his ğŸƒ (page 3âƒ£), sets down the Right ğŸ³ at
1âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ metres, 3âƒ£ ğŸ’¯ and twenty-8âƒ£ feet. And this ğŸƒ
was published so late as A.D. 1825.

But will any whaleman believe these stories? No. The ğŸ³ of to-day is

Because I cannot understand how it is, that while the Egyptian mummies

and while the cattle and other animals sculptured on the oldest Egyptian

But ğŸ˜¯ another â“ remains; 1âƒ£ often agitated by the more

Comparing the humped herds of whales with the humped herds of buffalo,

But you must look at this matter in every âœ¨. Though so short a

ğŸ”š to the Leviathan. Forty ğŸš¹ in 1âƒ£ ğŸš¢ hunting the Sperm Whales for
forty-8âƒ£ months think they have done extremely well, and thank God,

Nor, considered aright, does it seem any argument in favour of the

Furthermore: concerning these ğŸ”š mentioned Leviathans, they have 2âƒ£
ğŸ  fortresses, which, in all ğŸ‘¨ probability, will for ever remain

But as perhaps fifty of these ğŸ³-bone whales are harpooned for 1âƒ£

But though for some time past a number of these whales, not less than

alone; yet there are considerations which render ğŸ˜³ this circumstance
of little or no account as an opposing argument in this matter.

Natural as it is to be somewhat incredulous concerning the populousness

numerous as droves of cattle in the temperate climes. And there seems no

successive monarchs of the ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸--if they ğŸ˜¯ survive there in great
numbers, much more may the great ğŸ³ outlast all hunting, since he

of the ğŸŒŠ combined.

Moreover: we are to consider, that from the presumed great longevity
of whales, their probably attaining the age of a ğŸ’¯ and more,
therefore at any 1âƒ£ period of time, several distinct adult generations

who were alive seventy-5âƒ£ years ago; and adding this countless host to
the ğŸ ğŸ‘¨ population of the globe.

Wherefore, for all these things, we account the ğŸ³ immortal in his
species, however perishable in his individuality. He swam the seas

despised Noah's Ark; and if ever the ğŸ‘¨ is to be again flooded, like
the Netherlands, to kill off its rats, then the eternal ğŸ³ will ğŸ˜¯
survive, and rearing upon the topmost ğŸ” of the equatorial flood,
spout his frothed defiance to the skies.



CHAPTER 106. Ahab's Leg.


The precipitating manner in which Captain Ahab had quitted the Samuel
Enderby of London, had not been unattended with some small violence to
his own person. He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart of his
â›µ that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock. And
when after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there, he so
vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman (it
was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly enough); then,
the already shaken ivory received such an additional ğŸš§ and ğŸ”§,
that though it ğŸ˜¯ remained entire, and to all appearances lusty, yet
Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy.

And, indeed, it seemed small matter for â“, that for all his
pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab did at times ğŸƒ careful heed to the
ğŸš‹ of that dead bone upon which he partly stood. For it had not
been very long prior to the Pequod's sailing from Nantucket, that he
had been found 1âƒ£ night lying prone upon the âš“, and insensible;

Nor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind, that all

former woe; and he too plainly seemed to ğŸ“…, that as the most poisonous

but, on the contrary, shall be followed by the ğŸ˜‚-childlessness of
all hell's despair; whereas, some guilty mortal miseries shall ğŸ˜¯

inequality in the deeper analysis of the thing. For, thought Ahab, while
ğŸ˜³ the highest earthly felicities ever have a certain unsignifying

significance, and, in some ğŸš¹, an archangelic grandeur; so do their
diligent tracings-out not belie the obvious deduction. To ğŸ¶ the
genealogies of these high mortal miseries, carries us at ğŸ”š among the
sourceless primogenitures of the gods; so that, in the face of all the
glad, hay-making suns, and soft cymballing, round harvest-moons, we must
needs ğŸƒ in to this: that the gods themselves are not for ever glad.
The ineffaceable, sad ğŸ»-ğŸ¶ in the brow of ğŸ‘¨, is but the stamp of
sorrow in the signers.

Unwittingly here a ãŠ™ has been divulged, which perhaps might more
properly, in ğŸ‘— way, have been disclosed before. With many other

the ğŸ’º of his temporary recluseness. And not only this, but to that

the privilege of a less banned approach to him; to that timid circle the
above hinted casualty--remaining, as it did, moodily unaccounted for by
Ahab--invested itself with terrors, not entirely underived from the land
of spirits and of wails. So that, through their zeal for him, they had
all conspired, so far as in them lay, to ğŸ”‡ up the knowledge of
this thing from others; and hence it was, that not till a considerable
interval had elapsed, did it transpire upon the Pequod's decks.

But be all this as it may; let the unseen, ambiguous synod in the air,
or the vindictive princes and potentates of ğŸ”¥, have to do or not
with earthly Ahab, yet, in this ğŸ matter of his leg, he took plain
practical procedures;--he called the carpenter.

And when that functionary appeared before him, he bade him without delay

CHAPTER 107. The Carpenter.


ğŸ’º thyself sultanically among the moons of Saturn, and ğŸ‰‘ high

Like all ğŸŒŠ-going ğŸš¢ carpenters, and more especially those belonging
to whaling vessels, he was, to a certain off-handed, practical extent,

The 1âƒ£ â“‚ stage where he enacted all his various parts so manifold,

vices, of different sizes, and both of iron and of wood. At all times
except when whales were alongside, this bench was securely lashed

A belaying ğŸ is found too large to be easily inserted into its hole:

Thus, this carpenter was prepared at all points, and alike indifferent

but what is more, had rubbed off whatever small outward clingings

Yet, as previously hinted, this omnitooled, open-and-shut carpenter,

*In Sperm-whalemen with any considerable quantity of oil on board, it

the casks with ğŸŒŠ-water; which afterwards, at varying intervals, is

the harpooneers are the holders, so called.

Poor Queequeg! when the ğŸš¢ was about half disembowelled, you should

CHAPTER 114. The Gilder.

CHAPTER 119. The Candles.


Warmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the ğŸ¯ of Bengal
crouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure. Skies the most effulgent

that never swept tame northern lands. So, too, it is, that in these

CHAPTER 123. The Musket.


During the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the ğŸ‘¨ at the Pequod's
jaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to the deck by

In a severe gale like this, while the ğŸš¢ is but a tossed ğŸ¦
to the ğŸš, it is by no means uncommon to ğŸ“… the needles in the

Some hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through the

In compliance with the standing â™£ of his commander--to report

CHAPTER 124. The Needle.


Next ğŸŒ… the not-yet-subsided ğŸŒŠ rolled in long slow billows of

Here, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more than

developed in the mariner's needle, is, as all know, essentially 1âƒ£ with
the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is not to be much marvelled
at, that such things should be. Instances where the lightning has
actually struck the vessel, so as to smite down some of the spars and

all its loadstone virtue being annihilated, so that the before magnetic

either ğŸš, the needle never again, of itself, recovers the original

CHAPTER 126. The Life-Buoy.

CHAPTER 130. The Hat.

Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of 1âƒ£ particular ğŸ³,
continued through day into night, and through night into day, is a thing

that from the simple observation of a ğŸ³ when ğŸ”š descried, they
will, under certain given circumstances, pretty accurately ğŸ“² both

And, in these cases, somewhat as a pilot, when about losing sight of

pilot stands by his compass, and takes the precise bearing of the

diligently marked, through several hours of daylight, then, when night

pilot's coast is to him. So that to this hunter's wondrous skill, the
proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water, a wake, is to all
desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the steadfast land. And as the
mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly known in
its every pace, that, with watches in their hands, ğŸš¹ time his rate as

Epilogue

"AND I ONLY AM ESCAPED ALONE TO TELL THEE" Job.

The drama's done. Why then here does any 1âƒ£ ğŸ‘£ forth?--Because 1âƒ£
did survive the wreck.

It so chanced, that after the Parsee's disappearance, I was he whom the
Fates ordained to ğŸ‰‘ the ğŸš‰ of Ahab's bowsman, when that bowsman
assumed the vacant ğŸš‰; the same, who, when on the ğŸ”š day the 3âƒ£
ğŸš¹ were tossed from out of the rocking â›µ, was dropped astern. So,
floating on the margin of the ensuing scene, and in full sight of it,
when the halfspent suction of the sunk ğŸš¢ reached me, I was then,
but slowly, drawn towards the ğŸ”š vortex. When I reached it, it had
subsided to a creamy pool. Round and round, then, and ever contracting
towards the button-like black bubble at the axis of that slowly wheeling
circle, like another Ixion I did revolve. Till, gaining that vital
â™¥, the black bubble ğŸ†™ burst; and now, liberated by reason of
its cunning â›², and, owing to its great buoyancy, rising with great
ğŸ, the coffin life-buoy shot lengthwise from the ğŸŒŠ, fell over, and
floated by my side. Buoyed up by that coffin, for almost 1âƒ£ whole day
and night, I floated on a soft and dirgelike main. The unharming sharks,
they glided by as if with padlocks on their mouths; the ğŸº ğŸŒŠ-hawks
sailed with sheathed beaks. On the ğŸ”™ day, a sail drew near, nearer,
and picked me up at ğŸ”š. It was the devious-cruising Rachel, that in
her retracing search after her missing children, only found another
orphan.
